Zachary helped refine her writing by suggesting changes to sentence structure and wording, while Alice focused on adding scenes, highlighting the difference between a fiction writer and an editor or critic.

To raise money for charity, a newspaper and a TV company challenged brothers Jonny and Alistair Brownlee, who are champion triathletes, to participate in a unique race. This race would pit man against car and brother against brother. In the wild and mountainous Yorkshire Dales of northern England, Jonny and his younger brother Ali would race to the same destination. Jonny would drive a car on the roads, while Ali would ride a mountain bike across the countryside. "I’m looking forward to it," Jonny said at the start line. "I’ve never done anything like this before; it’s exciting! These roads have beautiful views, and it’s very cold right now, so I’ll be able to stay warm in the car." Alistair was just as eager, though he wore full winter cycling gear, unlike Jonny's jeans and sweatshirt. The cold didn’t affect his confidence. "To be honest," he said, "I’ve seen his driving before, so I’m not sure he’ll even make it. I might just stop for a cup of tea halfway up." The race began at the beautiful Semerwater lake in Wensleydale and was to end at Yorkshire’s highest road, Fleet Moss, about 350 meters up. This was no problem for the car, but Alistair’s first few miles involved a steep 25 percent incline, making it challenging from the start. After a quick handshake, they were off. Alistair sprinted away on his bike, heading up a hill and then across the countryside to Fleet Moss, while Jonny jumped in the car and hit the road. The next time they would see each other would be at the finish line. The question was, who would get there first? Jonny’s early confidence was quickly shaken. Just 15 seconds into the drive, he encountered his first obstacle: a giant tractor moving onto the road. "Welcome to Yorkshire," he complained to the cameraman in his car. "If Alistair beats me, it’s all because of this farmer!" After tense moments, Jonny was back on track, driving into the morning mist. Meanwhile, Alistair struggled with the slope. Just a couple of miles in, he had to dismount and carry his bike up the hill, past walls and over fences. Bemused sheep watched as the Olympic champion kept a steady pace, carrying his bike. Finally, he reached the summit. On the other side was open ground, and with the sun coming out, he had a chance to show his skills. Head down, feet on the pedals, Alistair picked up speed. In the car, Jonny faced another local challenge. The villages in this part of Yorkshire have existed long before cars, and the roads were not made for speed. Jonny carefully navigated a narrow corner and passed through a stream on the road. Once clear of the last village, he raced straight to the finish line. Neither brother knew how close the other was. As Jonny sped through the final stretch to Fleet Moss, Alistair was racing across his last field and back onto the road, approaching the finish from the other side. Head down, legs pumping, he reached the line with a squeal of brakes. Alistair looked up and asked the waiting crowd, "Is he here?" When they said no, he raised his arms in victory. Minutes later, Jonny arrived in the car and stepped out. "Well done," Jonny said, clearly disappointed. "I’m gutted."

Text: 'The silence is what you notice when playing on Centre Court at Wimbledon. You bounce the ball quietly on the soft grass; you toss it up to serve; you hit it and hear the echo of your shot. The trimmed grass, the rich history, the old stadium, the players in white, and the respectful crowds all create a cocoon from the outside world. The quiet helps my game. In a tennis match, I try hardest to focus only on the contest and the point I’m playing. The silence is broken by noise when a point ends: applause, cheers, people shouting your name. I hear them, but as if from far away. I don’t notice the fifteen thousand people watching every move my opponent and I make. I am so focused that I forget millions are watching me play Roger Federer in the 2008 Wimbledon final – the biggest match of my life. I always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. My uncle Toni, my lifelong coach, taught me early on that this was the most important tournament. By age 14, I was telling friends I’d play there one day and win. Before 2008, I played and lost twice, both times against Federer – in the final the year before, and the year before that. The 2006 defeat wasn’t so hard. I was just happy to have made it that far at twenty. Federer beat me easily, more easily than if I’d believed in myself more. But losing in 2007 left me devastated. I knew I could have done better; it wasn’t my ability that failed me, but my mindset. I cried for half an hour in the dressing room. Losing always hurts, but it hurts more when you have a chance and waste it. Toni, a tough coach, rarely comforts me; he criticizes even when I win. But seeing how upset I was, he told me not to cry, that there would be more Wimbledons and finals. I told him he didn’t understand, that this might have been my last chance. I know how short a professional athlete’s career is, and I want to make the most of it. Every moment counts, but some moments count more, and I let a big one pass in 2007. Toni couldn’t ease my grief, but he was right. Another chance came in 2008, just a year later. I was confident I’d learned from that defeat; this time, my mindset wouldn’t fail me. The best sign was my belief that I would win. At dinner with family, friends, and team members the night before the final, we didn’t talk about the match. I didn’t forbid it, but they knew I was already playing the match in my mind. Until the start of play, that space was mine alone.'

A young, idealistic Englishwoman named Jane Goodall arrived in Africa in April 1957. In one of her first letters home, she wrote, "I am living in the Africa I have always longed for, always felt stirring in my blood." She spent most of her life in Africa and became known as a citizen, journalist, scientist, activist, and environmentalist. In 1963, Britain's National Geographical Society helped make her famous by producing articles and documentaries about her research on chimpanzees. Her fame grew with her own writing, including children's books and the 1971 bestseller "In the Shadow of Man," translated into 47 languages.

Jane Goodall is one of the most celebrated female scientists of the 20th century, possibly second only to Marie Curie. However, her celebrity might have overshadowed her real achievements. Many articles and books about her life focus on her adventurous spirit, her privileged background, or her role as a feminist, which can undervalue her work. Based on academic references to her research, the success of her students, and the data from her 40-year study, Jane Goodall should be seen as a pioneering zoologist. Her main achievement is that she opened the door to understanding the social and emotional lives of chimpanzees.

Before Goodall's work, chimpanzees were seen as dangerous, and their behaviors were misunderstood. No one knew they ate meat or used tools. We didn't realize they shared emotions with humans or had social systems like ours. We also didn't know that chimpanzee communities had different cultural traditions. Her book, "The Chimpanzees of Gombe" (1986), is a key work in chimpanzee research. Her study in Gombe, Nigeria, is considered one of the great scientific achievements, according to biologist Stephen Jay Gould.

Jane Goodall changed how we study animals and how we think about ourselves, as chimpanzees are our closest relatives. Even as a child, she showed signs of her future career. At five years old, in 1939, she disappeared one afternoon. After a search, she reappeared with straw in her hair. She explained that she had hidden in a henhouse for five hours to see how hens lay eggs. This curiosity foreshadowed her career as a biologist.

During our first hour-long conversation, Shirley Ford speaks to me using the voice of a cheeky 8-year-old boy, the boy’s tired mother, a funny elderly Scottish woman, and a very fast-talking alien. Her voices are familiar to viewers of children’s TV and cartoons, and to those who have seen computerised employee programmes about health and safety. ‘I’ve just done a voiceover about back injuries,’ she says, ‘so I had to quickly learn how to pronounce many medical terms.’ Shirley discusses what it takes to do voiceovers. ‘Many actors, even well-known ones, think they can do funny voices, and many probably can,’ she says. ‘But there’s more to it than that. You have to bring the script to life for an audience who can’t see you. You wouldn’t believe how many famous people want to do voiceover work. Producers invite them to auditions for publicity, but often they don’t get parts because they’re used to acting with their whole bodies.’ After school, Shirley took a drama course, planning a standard acting career. During the course, she occasionally sang jingles for TV adverts. ‘One day,’ she says, ‘the man who ran the recording studio suggested I try out for the part of a rabbit in a cartoon soundtrack. It seemed silly – I hadn’t studied drama to play rabbits – but I tried it for fun and, surprisingly, got a major part.’ Shirley realized she could do voices and that voiceover work might be her path. ‘Things just happened for me,’ she says. ‘In my second film, I was lucky to play the main character – and her brother and mother.’ Adult female actors often provide voices for small boys and girls. Their voices are lighter than male actors, and hiring child performers involves complex procedures and endless forms, which production companies on tight schedules prefer to avoid. Shirley has learned to create the right sounds from the back of her throat, and to avoid always sounding like the same child, she collects new voices by watching children’s TV. Cartoons are the highlight of a job that includes everything from educational videos to vacuum cleaner adverts. ‘Those are hard because you have to sound enthusiastic about something you don’t care about, but my years in this profession help,’ she says. ‘They’ve taught me that the trick is to smile while you're talking – that makes your voice sound bright and cheery. When I have days doing animation work, it feels like a holiday; interacting with other actors makes a huge difference.’ The competition for work is tough, and a good showreel – a recording showing what the artist can do – is essential. ‘It’s definitely worth investing in a strong showreel,’ Shirley says. ‘There are agencies that specialize in helping voiceover artists put them together.’ She claims to have reached the top of her profession through persistence as much as natural ability. ‘Whether it’s making your showreel and taking it to all the film and TV companies, advertising agencies, and recording studios, or simply practicing your voices, it’s all about setting goals and not giving up.’ For anyone considering a career in voiceovers, Shirley recommends attending ‘specialist workshops – they cover all types of voiceover.’ She also believes a passion for human sound is essential, describing herself as obsessed with voices and, in a way, becoming the characters she performs. ‘If I’ve been in the studio doing a particular kind of American voice, for example, it can take over me and I’ll be speaking like that for hours, maybe even days afterwards,’ she says. ‘My children have grown up used to their mum talking in completely different voices.’

People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. This makes sense because cartooning is a dream job for many kids, like being a race car driver. However, most people eventually choose more practical careers, like becoming a tax lawyer or working in auto parts manufacturing. The idea of making a living by drawing doodles, like those in school notebooks, seems unrealistic. Yet, some people do just that. People become cartoonists in different ways, but most have wanted to do it for a long time. In my case, I had a typical cartoonist's childhood, loving comic strips and drawing for school publications. I studied graphic design in college and, after graduating, showed my illustrations to various companies. I was fortunate to find a newspaper looking for political cartoons on local issues. I created some ideas, they bought them, and within a few months, I was earning enough to support myself.

To become a cartoonist, you don't need a university degree, much money, or even great drawing skills. You just need your brain, your hand, and something to draw with. But if it were that easy, there would be as many cartoonists as teachers. The technical barriers are low, but it's still a challenging job. No one should try to become a cartoonist unless they feel they can't do anything else. It's easier to get a regular job that pays the bills and leaves time for family and hobbies. The more skills you have, the better your chances of making a living with your art. I've done political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I've also been a writer, caricaturist, and sometimes a designer. I don't turn down work because you can learn a lot from jobs you don't particularly want. It helps to be intelligent, well-read, and curious about the world.

What about the business side of cartooning? There was a time when many cartoonists could find regular work with newspapers and magazines, but those days are fading. Today, cartooning is mostly an entrepreneurial activity, meaning you have to create and sell your work. The more comfortable you are with this, the better you'll do. I've seen cartoonists with average talent and great business skills succeed more than artistic geniuses who lack business sense. It's surprising how many people fear their ideas will be stolen, even if they've never sold a cartoon. Some are so worried they won't let others see their work! Legally, to protect your work, you just need to draw a 'c' for 'copyright,' circle it, and write your name and the date. But realistically, it's more likely that no one will be interested in your work. If someone does steal a cartoon and it goes viral online, it might not be a disaster—it could be a lucky break!

Twenty years ago, I was moving house and decided to clear out some things. Among them was an electric guitar my dad gave me for my 16th birthday: a sleek, black, Japanese-made model. Despite my usual reluctance to throw things away, I decided to discard it. At the rubbish dump, just as I was about to throw it away, a young man approached me, surprised. "You’re not just going to throw that away, are you?" he asked. I admitted I was, already feeling a hint of regret. He asked if he could have it, and I agreed. We parted ways, but I felt a deep regret for years afterward.

Then, a few months ago, I received an email that changed everything. It reminded me of a story about a man who lost his wedding ring in the ocean and found it years later in a fish. The email was from Keith Rushton, a guitar dealer and restorer. He wrote, "I’ve got your electric guitar." The guitar had changed hands several times since the young man took it. Keith found a name-and-address label on the back, which my dad had put on everything I owned. Using my name, he tracked me down through the newspaper I work for and offered to sell it back to me. I was overwhelmed with emotion and agreed to his fair price.

My parents had encouraged me to learn classical guitar in the 1970s when it was popular. I loved its calming sound, but I struggled to progress. So, I switched to the electric guitar, playing simple tunes. It was also the era of punk music, where even those who couldn’t play well could be rock stars. When I received the guitar from Keith, I vividly remembered my birthday in 1978 when my parents gave it to me. Holding it again, it felt familiar yet smaller. I instinctively stood up, put a strap over my shoulder, and my fingers found the chords naturally. The electric guitar isn’t really a solo instrument, so now I’m learning it again, I might need to form a band. My son is learning the saxophone, so maybe we can play together. Or perhaps there are others my age with similar stories. We could call ourselves "The Regainers"!

There has been a lot of discussion about sleep recently. When I wrote the book "Insomniac," which is about people who struggle with sleeplessness, I felt like I was one of the few warning about the dangers of not getting enough sleep and how it affects our minds, bodies, and moods. Insomniacs, whom I interviewed in large numbers, will tell you that sleep is essential for our mental, physical, and social well-being. Those who struggle the most with sleep often understand its importance the best. It's good that sleep is finally getting the attention it deserves. But what about dreams? They haven't been discussed much. We often lose dreams when we wake up early, cutting off the last hour or two of sleep, which is mostly REM or 'Rapid Eye Movement' sleep, the stage rich in dreams. Our most vivid and emotionally powerful dreams happen during REM, just before we wake up. A good sleeper spends about a quarter of their sleep in REM, so someone who lives 90 years will spend six or seven years in REM. When researchers deprive people of REM, they experience more intense REM the next night to make up for it. This suggests dreams have a purpose. When REM was discovered in 1953, many agreed with psychologist Sigmund Freud, who believed that interpreting dreams was key to understanding our minds. However, later research did not support this idea, and the study of dreams shifted to their physical origins. Currently, there is little agreement among dream researchers, says Harvard sleep scientist Robert Stickgold. Dreams are important. At a meeting of the Associated Professional Sleep Society, P.F. Pagel from the University of Colorado Medical School presented a study showing that actors, writers, and directors remember and use dreams better than others. He concluded that dream use increases with interest in creativity. It makes sense that filmmakers have a strong connection to their dreams, as films are very dream-like. But I wondered, are only artistic people benefiting from dreams? Don't teachers, software designers, and politicians also need to think creatively? According to Stickgold, dreams help us combine ideas in new and surprising ways, using knowledge from the past and present to find new connections. Dreams might help us break free from usual thinking patterns. For example, Stickgold found that people woken from REM sleep give more original responses to words than those woken from other sleep stages. They make unexpected connections, which is what creativity is, says Stickgold. I write better after intense dreams. Even a troubling dream, even one barely remembered, seems to fuel creativity. On those days, words and images flow so quickly that my fingers can hardly keep up. I don't know how it works, but it does. Creativity isn't just for writers or artists. We live in a complex world and need our brains to function fully. We need to think creatively and flexibly in our relationships with colleagues, family, and friends. This is why we need to dream.

Twenty years ago, Susie Ray moved from London to a small coastal town in south-west England. In her studio, which has a stunning sea view, you see empty frames on the walls alongside photos of her two daughters. Susie is a pioneer in the copyist art movement, known for her ability to replicate the richness of early-20th century impressionist works and the brilliance of 16th-century Caravaggio portraits. Surprisingly, she doesn't keep any of her own work. "As soon as I finish them, they go," she says. Susie is in high demand. Over her 30-year career as a copyist, she has recreated works by famous artists like Renoir, Monet, and Van Gogh. Her reproductions are so accurate that even art experts can mistake them for originals. While the originals could sell for millions, her copies range from a few hundred pounds to £12,000, depending on the time she spends on them. Susie keeps her clients' identities mostly private, but they include galleries and private collectors. Some collectors are true art lovers, but status plays a role too. One celebrity claims to own a 'Van Gogh' when it's actually a 'Susie Ray Van Gogh.' "Many famous people pass off my copies as originals," she says. "That's up to them." Some collectors use her copies to save on insurance by keeping the original in a bank safe. Susie is transparent about her work. She aims to make her reproductions as authentic as possible, believing that doing otherwise would disrespect the original artist. She signs her name on the back of the canvas. Passing off a copy as an original is illegal, and although she knows people who have profited from it, she has never been tempted. Those who make fakes often face consequences. Susie isn't wealthy and has faced struggles, but her situation is more stable now, and risking her reputation isn't worth it. Susie wasn't always a copyist. After earning her art degree, she worked as an illustrator for a botanical garden, earning very little. It was a good foundation for her current work and sparked her love for plants, though it was hard to live on. She had to be very precise and get things right the first time. She has no regrets but is glad to have found something more financially rewarding. When young artists seek her advice, she emphasizes the importance of learning to draw accurately and the extensive study required for her work. Her skills allow her to do anything from drawing plants to copying 15th-century masterpieces to reproducing 20th-century abstract art. She now specializes in French impressionists, with Manet, Cezanne, and Degas as her favorites. Susie notes that people often think modern art is simple, almost like child's play. However, impressionists painted quickly yet meticulously, a challenging combination to master. Given her talent, it's surprising Susie doesn't create her own original art. Isn't art about self-expression? Could a Susie Ray original be worth more than a copy? She explains that her work is the result of years of training and dedication, and it provides a good living. She has tried creating her own art, like oil paintings of fishing nets, but they ended up looking like photographs—decent, but not exceptional. Susie is a perfectionist.

During her racing career, Ellen MacArthur was deeply passionate about the sea and being the fastest on it. From a young age, she was obsessed with sailing. She felt a unique connection with the boats that took her around the world, working in harmony with them. On land, everyday life seemed insignificant, and she quickly longed to return to the ocean, challenging herself against nature's forces, even in dangerous places. After finishing second in the Vendée Globe, a solo, non-stop round-the-world race, she showed me her boat, Kingfisher. It had been her home and survival space for 94 days. She explained the meticulous planning involved in her journey, down to the exact number of kitchen paper rolls she needed. Preparation was crucial, she said. She proudly displayed her supplies of freeze-dried food, a small gas stove, and neatly organized medical supplies. Her boat was her world, and she cared for it because her life depended on it.

Now, Ellen views the world like a boat: small, beautiful, and fragile, with limited resources. Her perspective changed during a trip to South Georgia, a remote island in the South Atlantic, where she participated in a bird survey. Seeing abandoned whaling stations made her reflect on humanity's tendency to exploit resources and move on. When I visited her office, she was finishing a passionate conference call about the urgent need to save the planet. She explained that coal, oil, and gas are finite resources, and we must find ways to conserve them. Initially, her message was about using less, but she realized the importance of reusing. She now advocates for sustainable practices, like reusable industrial carpet tiles.

For the past three years, Ellen has visited factories, mines, and power stations, discussing our dependence on non-renewable resources with governments and businesses. She admits she's not an expert but loves learning and absorbing information. The environmental crisis became something she couldn't ignore, making sailing seem selfish in comparison. She is focused on using her voice effectively to make a difference. Ellen also founded the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, a charity that encourages young people to rethink and redesign a sustainable future through business and education.

Although she misses the adventure of being at sea, which is a core part of her identity, she finds her new mission more fulfilling. At sea, she was connected to everything around her, focused on records and survival. Her current message is more complex than simply being the fastest around the world, but she believes it surpasses anything she has done before.

Jordan Romero is 13 years old and aims to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he succeeds, he could become a very famous teenager. As many young people spend more time on computers and games, he hopes to inspire them to climb their own mountains or at least spend more time outdoors. Jordan's climbing team includes his father, Paul, and mother, Karen. They call themselves 'Team Romero,' and climbing Everest is just part of their goal. If Jordan climbs Everest and Vinson Massif in Antarctica, he will be the youngest to complete the Seven Summits, the highest peaks on each continent. Few achieve this before turning thirty. Jordan has already climbed five of these peaks and might complete them before his teenage years end.

I spoke to several experienced Everest climbers, and none thought it was a good idea for a 13-year-old to climb the world's highest mountain. They agreed a young climber might be physically strong but doubted if a teenager would be emotionally ready. They also questioned if a young person could have enough experience to make safe decisions during such a climb. The Romeros are aware of these opinions. Paul says, 'I know there's criticism, but I can't focus on it – there's still so much to do. Karen and I consider the risks, but we trust our climbing experience. Watching Jordan grow gives me confidence. He's becoming strong and mature.'

I also question Jordan's motivation. Is this just an ambitious father pushing his love of adventure too far? Paul insists, 'This isn't about me seeking fame through my son's achievements. Initially, Jordan thought about doing this later, but we decided: why not now? We regularly check with him to ensure he remains motivated.' When I ask Jordan what he enjoys about the challenge, he says, 'I just focus on achieving my goal.'

In the past, few cared about being the youngest or fastest to climb a mountain or sail an ocean. Today, every adventure is shared online, and every climb becomes a record-setting challenge. The more daring the record, the more interest it attracts. This presents a challenge for Jordan. While we might say that achievement often overshadows enjoyment, if Jordan wants to inspire others, he must engage with the media. This involves blogging, photo shoots, and interviews. He needs to offer something extraordinary, like climbing Everest. 'And you know what?' Paul says. 'If Jordan decides tomorrow that he wants to stop climbing and play basketball instead, we'll end this project and head to the gym.'

Text: 'When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, it's likely they're not listening to classical music. Most people can name many pop groups, but if you ask my friends about Brahms, they probably won't know who he is. I'm studying music at university, but my classmates don't know much more about classical music than others our age. If you don't know the composers, you probably don't own their recordings. The statistics are discouraging for classical music fans. Only 3% of concert tickets sold last year were for classical music, and the average classical album sells just 300 copies. I find that surprising. So, why has interest in this centuries-old music declined? Older people blame TV and video games, but I don't think that's the reason. The truth is, classical music doesn't attract most people, especially teenagers, who are the main buyers of music and concert tickets. I know some teenagers who attend classical concerts, but they're a minority. Although I play in an orchestra, I'm not a big classical music fan. I enjoy many styles, but my classical music collection is probably close to that 3% figure. Why don't teenagers like classical music? First, the pace and rhythm, with many mood changes, are challenging for us. We like to talk, play, and think fast. Experts say we struggle to focus for more than three minutes, which is too short for most classical pieces but perfect for a pop song. Pop is simple and easy to listen to, while classical music needs time and focus. Pop music topics are more appealing than long classical pieces without lyrics. Classical music is powerful but doesn't address teenage concerns. How we listen to music has changed. In the past, families made music together at home, and playing an instrument was valued. The only other way to hear music was at a concert. Now, you can find any music online, but our lives rarely feature classical music. When did you last hear classical music in a shop? One of my teachers says classical concert audiences have grown recently. Maybe, but I doubt many are teenagers. In my orchestra, we play classical music in various places, but I mostly see older people in the audience. I don't know why people prefer classical concerts in middle age, but if your parents love something, you're likely to avoid it as a teenager. Some blame schools for teenagers' lack of interest in classical music, but many kids are eager to play in school orchestras. They arrive early to practice and stay after school to rehearse. Classical music interests them when performing, but it's not their first choice for listening. The two activities have become separate. When we relax, it's always pop music.'

Bonnie Wyndham stepped out of her mother’s car and looked at Almonside School. "I’ll make you regret my presence here," she said to the school, with a hint of amusement. Her mother, who was getting out from the other side, didn’t hear her, but Bonnie wouldn’t have minded if she had. Her mother was aware of her feelings. Mrs. Wyndham surveyed the surroundings. Almonside was an unusual school, with various buildings hidden among the trees on a wooded hillside; it seemed confusing at first glance. Then she noticed the signs on a post: Science block, gymnasium, riding centre… "Riding centre," Bonnie remarked, suddenly interested. "Headmaster’s study," her mother replied. "This way." Bonnie followed her mother along a wide path that curved through the trees. "I wish you’d walk beside me instead of trailing behind like a dog," Mrs. Wyndham said tiredly, though she didn’t seem to expect Bonnie to comply. A few minutes later, her mother was speaking with Bonnie’s new headmaster in his study, while Bonnie waited outside. Suddenly, Bonnie stood up. "Why should I just sit here?" she thought. "I’ll be expelled soon enough," she mused to the door, "so why not speed things up?" She left the building and headed towards the riding centre, following the sign. There was a charming old building for the horses and a large indoor riding arena. Bonnie looked around, but no one was there. She approached the horses with a certain respect. Bonnie always treated horses with care. She could immediately tell that the horses were well cared for. Almost every stall was occupied, and she walked along, examining each horse carefully. "I know what they’re doing here," she told a small pony, running a finger along its nose. The next horse caught her attention. "Aren’t you the best of the lot!" she exclaimed. He was brown with a touch of white. Probably lively, but Bonnie liked that. "I feel like we’ve met before," Bonnie said, stroking his neck. "In my dreams, I was riding you to victory in a big competition…" His name was Maverick, according to the sign above the stall. Suddenly, she couldn’t resist the urge to ride him. "I wonder where I can find a bridle and a saddle for you. They must be nearby." The room with all the riding equipment was, to Bonnie’s delight, unlocked. Absorbed in the enjoyable task of saddling Maverick, she forgot all about her mother and the headmaster. Once she was seated high on the big horse outside, she felt like a queen, ruler of all she surveyed. Her nickname at her previous school had been Queen Bee, and she laughed as she remembered it. "You’re the best horse I’ve ever ridden, Maverick," she said admiringly, "and I’m not exaggerating, because I know horses, even if I don’t know much else." She nudged him into a walk, then a trot. "If I stay here, I think you and I could become great friends," she confided. She rode around the paddock. The rhythm was exhilarating, a breeze brushing her cheek and making it glow. She could tell Maverick trusted her, and she felt sure he’d jump well.

I've met Cody Simpson before and have always been impressed by his quiet confidence. The 15-year-old Australian has already released several successful songs. So how did a laid-back surfer end up on stage in front of thousands of fans? "I first picked up a guitar when I was six years old and started writing songs when I was seven," Cody says, recalling how it all began. "But I was swimming every day and surfing. Those were the things that meant more to me back then; I had my life set up and so much to occupy my time. I was 13, going to high school, and then I posted a few videos online." These videos changed everything. He began with a video of a friend and himself singing at a school concert. Fans sent online comments saying they wanted more of his videos on their social networking sites. So Cody, who had recorded some more at home, was happy to oblige. The responses were overwhelming. Cody was a very talented swimmer. He was training hard with some of the best coaches and focusing on perfecting his sport. But then record labels came calling, and he had a tough choice to make: stay in Australia and continue swimming, or take a huge risk by signing a deal and moving with his entire family to the US. Cody decided to take the plunge. "It was very difficult for me—especially at such a young age—to have to choose a career for myself. Can you imagine, at 12 or 13 years old, trying to figure out what you want to do for the rest of your life?" He had to tell his swimming coach and his friends that he was moving to the States. "It came as a big surprise to most people. I'm kind of the quiet kid," he says, remembering their shocked expressions. "I'm very modest, and I think it's important to be that way in this crazy world." So Cody packed his bags and went with his family halfway around the world, giving up one dream in the hope of making another come true. Although his family stays out of the spotlight and isn't directly involved in his career, they are there in the background. Cody says it's important to keep a tight circle of great people around you to make sure your feet stay on the ground. Of course, we all have days of doubt. "Sometimes when I'm left alone for a while, I sit and think, 'How did my decision affect my little brother and sister?' My little brother's eight years old, and he's traveling the world, doing school on the road; he doesn't have a regular life," Cody admits. "I worry about the effect of that on him sometimes, but my family's always reassuring me that they're here to support me and encourage me in everything that I do." Success, in whatever career you choose, comes from a willingness to say "yes" to your big break, even when it's a little scary to do so. "It all just happened so fast and unexpectedly," Cody says. "Now, to be going to countries I never thought I'd visit in my life, and to be playing in front of hundreds of thousands of fans—it's like something that I think lots of people dream of and try to achieve. But I know it won't last forever."

I jumped out of bed, pulled back the bedroom curtain, and looked at the river bend. A new crack in the ice sparkled in the morning sun. I shaded my eyes and looked upstream at the sandbag wall, which was there to protect the buildings from flooding as the ice melted. My back still hurt from lifting those sandbags into place. Last week, I worked long hours with most of the town's adults, showing I could handle it. But my grandfather didn't seem to notice. With one hand on the curtain, I looked at the half-mile stretch of steaming black water from the wood factory in Milltown. Fragile ice was on either side, with solid ice downstream. As I changed into my kayaking wetsuit, I saw a boy on the far side of the river. I didn't recognize him. He was trying to balance on an ice shelf near the warm water from the factory. I zipped up my wetsuit and grabbed my kayaking jacket. I checked the pocket for the lucky silver chain my famous grandfather brought back from South America. It's better than having a famous grandfather because only he, my mom, and I know about it. Plus, I have his diary from that journey, which I read before bed. I patted the chain and headed to the kitchen. "Morning, Rex," Mom said as I took a banana from the counter. "You're up early for a Saturday. I'll make brunch after your training. Be careful." "Thanks, Mom." I walked down the hallway and almost bumped into Grandpa. "Watch where you're going," he shouted. "Where are you going?" "Sorry, Grandpa. I'm going kayaking." As if my wetsuit didn't make that clear. Grandpa is Grandpa, and I try to ignore his temper, but it's getting harder. "Why train? You didn't win the competition," he said. His words stung, but I took a deep breath and counted to three. He slammed the bathroom door. Mom gave me a sympathetic smile. "Don't mind him. He's..." "...not himself," I finished. I didn't say he's always been like that. But, like Mom, I try to be patient. As a child, he was my hero, showing me his National Geographic photos. Those photos still hang in his room, above his dusty medals and trophies. But I don't go in there anymore. I have my own trophies now and hope to be in National Geographic someday. Yet, part of me still wants to admire him, despite his temper. Mom smiled. "At least he's coming out of his room more. Have a good session, Rex. I admire your dedication, even in the cold!" I smiled back, peeling my banana. "It'll be warmer in South America," I said. "If I find sponsors for my expedition." She laughed and went back to the kitchen. I ate my banana and went downstairs. In the backyard, I hurried to the boathouse.

Mum grabbed Jess by the arm. "Come with me," she said. Jess followed her to the study. On the table, leaning against the wall, was an unframed painting. It was clearly Grandpa's work, but different from anything he had done before, and it was obviously unfinished. "Do you know anything about this?" Mum asked. Jess shook her head. "I've never seen it before. I didn't know he was working on anything." Jess looked at the picture. A river dominated the scene; it wasn't a river she recognized and might not even be real, just a fantasy. The picture was strange and shapeless, yet beautiful in a mysterious way. The riverbank was barely noticeable, just a hint of green, drawing the eye into the pale waters and towards a hidden sea. There were no animals, birds, or people, and it felt right that way. It seemed like there was no place for living things in this distant vision. Yet, for some reason, she was fascinated, thinking of autumn coming after a long, rich summer. Mum spoke again. "It has a name." Her voice sounded too casual, too detached, revealing her excitement. Jess understood why. Grandpa never named his paintings. He just painted them and let others interpret them, if they could. Mum turned the picture over and pointed to the words Grandpa had written. Jess read them aloud. "River Boy." The words seemed to have a strange importance to her, though she couldn't say why. And there was another mystery. She looked at Mum. "There is no boy." "Exactly. Strange, isn't it? For him to be so specific. Still, he hasn't finished it yet, so maybe he's going to add the boy later. I made the mistake of asking him about it." "Mum! You should have known better." "I know, but I couldn't resist. It's such an unusual picture, especially having a name. I suppose you can guess his response." Jess didn't need to guess. She knew what Grandpa would have said. "He told you it's not up to the artist to explain a painting because each picture has its own life and language, like a poem, and we either understand it or we don't. And he said painting is hard enough without having to waste time telling every idiot..." "Ignoramus, he said." "...every ignoramus what it means. And if artists had to explain their pictures to everyone who came along, they'd never get any work done. And he said..." Mum interrupted, laughing. "Something like that. Anyway, I was hoping you might know something about this painting, since you seem to be a sort of muse for him." "Muse?" "Someone who inspires an artist." She knew what the word meant. Grandpa often used it when she watched him paint, but usually just to say the muse wasn't being kind to him that day, or that he'd have to be nice to the muse because he had a difficult part to work on, or something like that. He never suggested the muse had anything to do with her. She always thought he meant some kind of goddess, not a human being. And it was hard to imagine anyone, even a goddess, influencing someone as stubborn as Grandpa. "He doesn't need me to inspire him," she said. "He's been painting all his life."

When I woke up this morning, I didn't plan to cut a hole in my bedroom carpet. I'm not saying it was an accident, but it could have been. For example, if I had tripped over the bed with Dad's Stanley knife in my hand, the blade might have accidentally cut the carpet. I'm not saying that happened, just that it could have. I didn't wake up thinking, "Today I will cut a hole in my carpet." It just seemed like a good idea at the time, as things often do. Later, you wonder why you thought that, but by then it's too late. This happens to me a lot. I'm quite unlucky that way. 

What I was actually doing was trying to fit my corner cabinet into a corner. Gran gave me the cabinet when she moved to a flat. It's really cute—small, painted white, with pink and blue flowers around the edge, and tiny glass-panelled doors. Gran used to keep china ornaments in it: shepherdesses, milkmaids, and old-fashioned ladies selling balloons. I keep my collection of shells, fossils, and interesting stones there. Gran knew I always loved her corner cabinet, so I was thrilled when she gave it to me! But it's a corner cabinet, shaped like a triangle, so it has to stand in a corner. 

I only have two corners in my bedroom because it's the smallest room in the house, shaped like a wedge of cheese. The big front bedroom is Mum and Dad's; the one at the back is my sister Angela's; the little one over the garage is my brother Tom's; and the tiny one, like a broom cupboard, is mine. Mum says when Angela goes to University, Tom can have her room, and I can have his. And when Tom goes to University, I can choose. But since Angela is only fifteen, it seems I'll be in my broom cupboard for years. I don't really mind; I like my little bedroom. It's cosy, like a nest. I love the sloping roof and the window at floor level. The only problem is the lack of corners! My bed is in one, and my wardrobe in the other. I tried fitting Gran's cabinet between the roof and the floor, but it was just a bit too tall. If I could only take a couple of centimetres off the bottom of it... 

Then it came to me. If I couldn't cut anything off Gran's cabinet, how about cutting a hole in the carpet? It seemed like the obvious solution. What Dad calls lateral thinking. I thought he would be pleased with me. He always tells us to "think outside the box." And that's exactly what I was doing!

The novel 'The Borrowers' is about a family of tiny people who live hidden in the walls and floors of a house. They secretly 'borrow' things from normal-sized people to survive. When I was asked to direct a TV adaptation of the novel, I knew it would be challenging to meet fans' expectations. Fans of the book have clear ideas about how everything should look. I relied a lot on the original drawings from the book because I didn't want people to criticize me for getting it wrong. The author wanted the series to be from the Borrowers' perspective, not a human one, which made filming more complex. The most important thing was getting the scale right. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans, so if we filmed them walking across a room or on a borrowing mission, we had to be 10 times further away than usual. When filming the human surroundings, the crew had to crawl on the ground and film from no higher than 15 centimeters to get the Borrowers' perspective. They wore out many pairs of jeans doing this! We never raised the cameras above their height except for aerial shots. One big challenge was getting the shadows right when combining images of the tiny Borrowers with normal-sized backgrounds. We developed a unique technique for this. After the series aired, the famous US film director George Lucas called to ask how I did it. The only permanent set we built was the Borrowers' home under the floorboards, filled with giant objects to make the actors look small. It was wonderfully surreal. When I asked them to carry things like a giant pair of scissors, they really got into it. I especially remember the coins—they were bigger than dinner plates and hard to lift. We often had to stop filming because they made the crew laugh so much. In the story, there's a scene where the Borrowers are swept down a drain. To film this, actors had to be swept down a tunnel with hoses, and they said it was so frightening they didn’t have to act. One important thing for me, which other directors struggled with, was getting the costumes right. I had them made from heavy canvas so they stuck out like dolls' clothes. This made it nearly impossible for the lead actress to bend in her costume. She couldn’t sit during breaks and had to be sewn into the dress every morning. The lead actor's trousers were made from a rug because normal material would have looked too smooth. Unfortunately, the weather was really hot during filming. I don’t think they thanked me for my attention to detail with those costumes! Most of the action away from the Borrowers’ home was shot with actors separated from their surroundings. We filmed them in front of a blue screen on an empty set. It was challenging for them to react to things that weren't there. I had to draw pictures of every scene to show how each should look—I did 2,000 by the end. They weren’t accurate, but they worked well enough. The budget didn’t allow for time in special effects studios during the day, so I worked nights for three months. We had to work hard and fast—I once shot a whole scene before realizing there was no film in the camera. But it all came together in the end, and I think the series successfully conveyed the magic of the books.

Mom stops the car at the corner of my new school, Palm Grove High. She looks around nervously, checking for journalists who aren't there. I wonder how long it will take before the chaos starts. It always does. The fake smiles, the wannabe friends, the "can-you-get-me-free-tickets-to-your-dad’s-concerts?" requests. "Everything’s going to be fine," I reassure her. She kisses her fingertip and touches my cheek before I get out. Then she drives off, leaving me to face this new school and situation. But this is what I wanted—to leave my old life on the road and with tour tutors. While the band is renting here for recording, we’re staying permanently. I insisted on attending this school to meet real kids. Maybe a kid with a mom who works in an office or a dad who mows lawns. That would be so normal. I enter the school’s main office. "Hi, I need my schedule, please," I say to the secretary. "Name?" She looks as friendly as an ice bucket. "Desert McGraw." "Desirée?" she asks, leaning closer. "Desert," I repeat. She seems confused. "Oh," she says and types "McGraw" on her keyboard. That’s one good thing. Few people recognize my last name because my dad uses his stage name. "What grade?" "Eleventh." "One second, it’s printing," she says, then hands me the sheet. English Literature, first period. Great, I can handle that. English is my favorite subject. I’ll be late, though. English is in Room 214, second floor. I studied the map last night to avoid looking lost. When I reach the door, the teacher is already taking roll. "Aurelio Gonzalez." "Here." I slip in quietly and sit at the last desk in the second row. The girl next to me smiles, looking at my outfit—jeans and a T-shirt. Ha! No one will suspect me now! "Nice shoes," she whispers. I glance at my expensive platforms with embroidered flowers. Oh no, I knew I shouldn’t have worn these. Dead giveaway. "Thanks," I say. The teacher pauses. "Desert... McGraw?" she says hesitantly. "Here." She smiles and introduces herself as Ms. Smigla. She talks a lot and gives us our course outlines. After reviewing them and discussing the books we’ll read, she lets us socialize! All teachers should do this. "So why’d you move here?" my new friend asks. I have options. Do I say I wanted a normal life away from cameras and reporters? Or the real reason, according to Dad? "We need a change, Desert," he said, "and this is the perfect place to record the new album. Energy, color, culture... just what our last album needed." Essence? I think he just wants to relax on the beach. Why else choose South Beach Sounds, a studio near the sand? "My dad had to relocate," I tell her. Yes, lies work better. "What does he do?" she asks. Oh well, everyone will find out eventually. But I’ll pretend to be normal until then. "He’s an artist," I say, playing with my backpack zipper. "Cool. I’m Becca, by the way." And she doesn’t seem to care. Perfect.

Text: 'The average American teenage girl today is expected to be the Student Council president, have a part-time job, volunteer, and excel in all these areas. This is the reality for American teenagers now. They can't just go to school and stay unnoticed, because being average is no longer enough. Mediocrity is not acceptable, and lacking ambition is seen as laziness. "People, often adults, forget how much pressure teenagers face these days. We have lots of homework, tests, extra-curricular activities, jobs, chores, and responsibilities at home, all while trying to maintain a social life," says teenager Kristen Loose. Despite these pressures being normal for teenagers today, negative stereotypes about them still exist, often spread by the media. You know the stereotypes: lazy, disrespectful, rebellious, loud, reckless, and self-absorbed. While there is some truth to these, it's not fair to label the entire generation this way. "Many people assume we spend most of our time watching TV and using our cell phones," Loose says. She believes this is mostly wrong. She admits to keeping her cellphone nearby, but not just for fun. It's not just for texting friends; it's a tool that teens use to make their lives easier. Students today are expected to have immediate access to the world and be reachable at all times, which can seem like a cell phone addiction. With smartphones, tablets, and social media, students can now do their work anywhere, even on the go. Instead of listening to music on the way to school, they might listen to language lessons. Schoolwork and other activities no longer stop at the school gate; they require 24-hour attention from already busy teens. Many teenagers start their days around 6 a.m. or 7 a.m. and often end after midnight. Their schedule is full of school, after-school activities, family duties, and homework. Then, they have to get up and do it all again the next day, often with less than the recommended nine hours of sleep. The US National Sleep Foundation found that only about 20 percent of teens get the recommended nine hours of sleep a night. Moreover, 28 percent of teens admitted falling asleep in school about once a week due to lack of sleep. Teenager Lindamarie Olsen says that after all her activities, she gets about 18 hours of free time a week. With 168 hours in a week, 18 is not much. Olsen rarely spends this time on social media or TV. Instead, she focuses on volunteer work. "I think the stereotype of teenagers is that they only care about themselves and their immediate interests," Olsen says. Despite this image, Olsen's favorite part of the week is volunteering. "I love serving others and look forward to making a positive impact in my school and community." In 20 years, who knows what the stereotype for teenagers will be, but they will still be proving it wrong and pushing the world forward. There will be another generation of students taking the world by storm, all before they finish school.'

The teenage members of the Earth to Sky Calculus Club live in and around Bishop, a mountain town in the US, east of the Sierra Nevada mountain range. This group has launched over fifty balloons to the edge of space, about 35 km above the Earth's surface. Their project is both a science experiment and an adventure, which attracts teenagers. I joined them one weekend in late spring. They were about to release a high-altitude balloon to record shooting stars. These occur when a rock or metal piece enters the Earth's atmosphere, creating a light trail. As night fell, the teenagers attached a soft insulated $5 lunch box to the balloon. Inside was a camera, an altitude instrument, and a thermometer. Two GPS trackers were outside the lunch box to help find it later. A gas tank, donated by someone from a neighboring state, inflated the balloon to the size of a small car. An older boy had made a seven-hour trip to get it. ‘I didn’t really mind,’ he said. For these kids, such efforts are normal. Finally, it was time for lift-off. ‘Five, four, three, two, one,’ they chanted, and the balloon began its ascent. Some ran and tracked its path with flashlights, lighting up the balloon in the dark sky. There was a quiet sense of wonder. Then the balloon vanished into the night. After the launch, most students went home, but a few stayed to watch the shooting stars. They lay on blankets on the mountainside, under a clear sky, just four hours from Los Angeles, a busy city of about 4 million people. I saw a boy climb into a sleeping bag and fall asleep. ‘We’re the only ones talking,’ said one girl softly. ‘I know,’ whispered another. A meteor streaked across the sky. As the balloon rose, the air pressure decreased, and the balloon expanded until it was almost the size of a house. Then it burst. A parachute helped the lunch box land safely. The students would find it the next day using the GPS trackers. Recovering it wasn’t easy, but that was part of the fun. The area around Bishop is mostly uninhabited, so the lunch box usually lands in remote places. ‘Recoveries are a big part of the program,’ said the group’s leader, noting they’ve lost only two lunch boxes in 53 launches. ‘We’ve become more familiar with this landscape in ways we wouldn’t normally.’ This time, the lunch box landed 84 km west of Bishop. To reach it, the team had to drive south of the Sierra and then back up the western side. They had to decide whether to drive or walk, as it could be dangerous if the lunch box was on a high peak or a tall tree. ‘These students are native to the Eastern Sierra,’ their leader said. ‘What seems wild to some is normal to them.’ It took them 11 hours to find the lunch box. It was in a canyon, on a flat rock, in a waterfall. The camera didn’t record any shooting stars. It was disappointing, but it was a chance to discuss atmospheric waves and how they work over mountains. And it was another adventure story to share.

Chloe Morgan admits that science, especially Palaeontology, didn't interest her much until she was fifteen. Her interest began by chance when she helped her younger brother with a science project. She found an article about recent discoveries in Palaeontology, which fascinated her. Chloe decided then that she wanted to pursue this field. 

I asked her about the support she received, as Palaeontology was not a common career choice for young people at that time. She recalls meeting her first professional palaeontologist, Matt Cornelius, who was already famous despite being young. Chloe was nervous about meeting him, fearing he might find her questions annoying. However, she felt comfortable when he showed patience and was willing to listen.

We discussed how palaeontologists are portrayed in movies and TV shows. Chloe acknowledges that films like Jurassic Park have increased public interest in dinosaurs, but not necessarily in Palaeontology. She finds the portrayal of palaeontologists in films misleading, often depicting them as eccentric geniuses or geeky figures. She feels that films do not accurately represent their daily work.

Chloe explains that her job is varied. She spends time digging up dinosaur bones, working in laboratories, analyzing fossils, and writing for scientific publications. Although not a daily task, she also communicates scientific findings to the public. Chloe believes it's important to address misunderstandings about science and enjoys reaching out to young people to inspire them about the natural world.

Chloe was involved in the TV documentary Walking with Dinosaurs, where she advised on the accuracy of dinosaur portrayals. She praises the program's creators for their knowledge and says her role was mainly to ensure the dinosaurs shown coexisted in the same time period. The documentary attracted audiences of all ages because it depicted dinosaurs more accurately than films like Jurassic Park.

I asked Chloe why dinosaurs continue to fascinate us and remain a focus of research. She believes they appeal to our innate curiosity and the desire for discovery. Dinosaurs remind us that there is still much to explore, and Palaeontology offers a form of time travel.

Text: "Let me say this clearly: when you're on a car trip with your family, even at six years old, you probably know you're not 'there yet,' even if you keep asking 'Are we there yet?' Once you arrive, it's not 'there' anymore; it's 'here.' So, if you think you might be 'there,' you should ask 'Are we here yet?' No one wants to be 'there' more than the parents who hear that question repeatedly on long trips. Really, what are we kids complaining about? Think about it. Wouldn't you rather relax in the back seat, with nothing expected of you? You can watch DVDs, listen to music, or do puzzles, while the scenery passes by outside. In the front seat, mum or dad is there to hand out snacks, change the radio, and keep everything running smoothly. Are we there yet? I hope not. That is, until someone does something annoying—like my younger brother, Tim, putting his foot on my side of the seat. He can't do that! So I put my foot on his side. Then it's his other foot, then a hand, and soon he's in my space, and a fight starts. The driver and co-pilot separate us as the car swerves. They tell Tim to stay in his seat and keep his hands to himself. Peace returns for a while. The scenery continues to pass by. Then, as I'm trying to read, I feel a draught on my arm. The window isn't open, so where's it from? Tim is next to me, quietly blowing air on me. He's on his side, not touching me, so he's technically not doing anything wrong. Just breathing? What's the problem? The anger rises. Tim gets scolded, the car swerves again. Then calm returns—for now. Over the years, Dad has developed ways to handle us in the back seat. For example, when we ask 'Are we there yet?' he often says, 'Yes. Get out of the car.' 'But Dad, we're still on the highway.' 'Oh, maybe we're not there yet.' That keeps us quiet for a while. You know you're finally 'there' when the adults get out of the car and move away from the kids who have annoyed them for hours. So remember: if mum and dad are close enough to answer your question, then no, you're not there yet."

John and Zuzi Morgan have opened a café in Oxford, UK, where visitors can enjoy coffee, cake, and play board games. They hope people will love the experience and return. Zuzi explains their motivation: "With so much technology, everyone is busy on their phones. We wanted to bring people together without screens. It's natural for us to communicate face-to-face."

The games at their café are called 'Eurogames', known for gentle themes like farming. The first Eurogame was The Settlers of Catan, created by German designer Klaus Teuber. In this game, players build settlements and trade resources, keeping everyone engaged. This idea evolved into 'co-operative' games, where players win or lose as a team, encouraging social interaction. Pandemic, a Eurogame by North American designer Matt Leacock, requires players to solve global problems together. Leacock was inspired by a Eurogame based on Lord of the Rings. He recalls, "Playing it with friends was thrilling. Everyone felt good, win or lose. I wanted to create something similar."

Leacock's love for board games began in childhood. He often felt disappointed with games, so he and his uncle would redesign them. Pandemic became a huge success, and its sequel added storytelling elements, similar to video games, where characters develop and the world changes.

Interestingly, the video game industry's growth has helped board games succeed. Video games have made gaming more common, and many people now play games on their smartphones. Ben Hogg, from a leading games company, notes, "Everyone's a mobile gamer now. More people are open to playing games."

Initially, video games offered social interaction in arcades or through multiplayer games at home. But as multiplayer gaming moved online, players became physically distant. Some people who enjoyed video games started seeking in-person gaming experiences again. John and Zuzi's café shows that tabletop gaming is more than just fun. In our online world, these games offer a way to connect in person, and this trend is likely to grow.

Jamie Scott has written and produced some of the biggest UK hits in recent years. His story shows why endurance and persistence are crucial in the music industry, even if your career starts with setbacks. Jamie's mother, an excellent singer, introduced him to the guitar. Growing up, he only listened to a local radio station for middle-aged people, which influenced his musical tastes. He didn't hear a contemporary song until he was 12. Around that time, he had to choose between tennis, which he played at a national level, and music. He spent his lunchtimes in the school music room, playing the piano. Although he was good at tennis, he realized it wasn't his passion. At 17, he left school to pursue a music career. He formed a duo with a friend who was a decent guitarist but not as committed to a music career. Jamie told his parents about his dream, explaining that he wrote lyrics during economics lessons and played the piano while others played outside. His father gave him 18 months to succeed, or he would have to find a job. After some close calls with record labels, he signed with a music publisher at 19, thanks to one song. However, record labels wanted him as a solo artist, so he parted ways with his friend. Ultimately, he found success behind the scenes rather than on stage. After a challenging time with a UK record label, he switched to another label to release a new album, but fame and fortune didn't follow. Jamie feels that as an artist, he was often in the wrong place at the wrong time, but as a writer, he was in the right place. Writing for others became his strength. He believes he is one of the main writers UK labels rely on to help launch new artists' careers. Sometimes, he explains to artists that aiming for chart success is nothing to be ashamed of. He asks them, "Don't you want 10 million people streaming your music next month?" He emphasizes creating songs that are both amazing and likely to sell well. In a world of false modesty in pop music, Jamie speaks openly about wanting to write number-one hits. He isn't arrogant; he simply knows he has a talent for it. Instead of worrying about others' opinions, he focuses on his goal. "That's the endgame when I go into the studio," he says. "We aim to write the best music of next year, not just what's cool. We want to create classic modern pop songs."

Tony Connor is a new kind of celebrity: a big star online, but probably unknown to those who don't watch online videos of bike stunts. He is a 'street trials cyclist', performing jumps from places like roofs or walls to other unusual spots. These stunts are filmed and shared online. When I meet him for an interview at a BMX park on a Saturday morning, the local boys recognize him immediately. Even older people come by to praise him, calling him 'an absolute legend'. After seeing his skills, I agree with them. Initially skeptical, I am impressed by his bravery, creativity, and willingness to take risks. Before each stunt, he explains his plan, and I often doubt he can succeed. Yet, when I praise him, he seems indifferent and somewhat downcast. Despite his online fame, Tony admits he is a reluctant celebrity. He finds the social aspect challenging and prefers doing things over discussing them. This is ironic since his fame comes from social media and the camera technology that fuels it. He acknowledges that this technology allows people like him to earn a living. However, he feels uneasy about everyone constantly filming themselves or staring at screens. Still, he doesn't complain, as the videos provide him a good income from what would have been just a hobby in the past. From years of interviewing top athletes, I've learned that two key factors turn an enthusiastic child into an elite competitor: energy and the ability to overcome emotional setbacks. These qualities may be more important than talent and help athletes persist despite failures. In riskier sports, mental strength is crucial. Even in the park, Tony fell a few times on relatively easy but unfamiliar obstacles. He simply got up and tried again until he succeeded. Not everyone sees Tony as a hero. Some think he is reckless and takes unnecessary risks. He responds that these critics are not well-informed and likely have never ridden a trials bike. They don't understand the technical aspects of his sport or that he consults experts to minimize risks. Tony is careful about the risks he takes. He believes it's wise to be aware of dangers. People who never feel scared probably shouldn't do these sports. He divides people into those who can't overcome fear and those who can. He belongs to the latter group, feeling fear but finding a way past it. He is not addicted to risk and spends hours planning and preparing. Sometimes he rides around to get in the right mindset before attempting a new stunt. He knows he mustn't lose his nerve before a jump. If he fully commits, he is fine.

Television presenter Helen Skelton has taken on several dangerous challenges for charity, such as running a marathon in the desert and traveling down the Amazon River in a small boat. Her latest challenge involved walking on a high wire, a long thin piece of metal, 66 meters above the ground, between two towers of an empty power station. There was no safety net, only a belt around her waist connected to another wire above. To help her balance and avoid falling, she carried a long stick weighing eight kilograms. Helen trained with an expert high-wire walker. Although she had some circus skills, she quickly learned that high-wire walking was very different. "The training was a shock," said Helen. "I didn’t realize how strong I’d need to be. Every day started at 8 am with a run up a steep hill, followed by an hour of exercises, and another hour after practicing on the wire. I also had to learn how to fall onto the wire so that if I slipped, I could continue. Every time I fell on the wire, it hurt a lot. But it was important to stay positive: if I was nervous and started shaking, so would the wire!" On the day of the challenge, it was windy, and Helen calmed herself by taking deep breaths as she moved step by step along the wire. The 150-meter walk took 15 minutes. "That was the scariest thing I’ve done," she admitted afterward. "I’m glad it’s over!" Despite this, Helen is already planning her next charity project: to reach the South Pole by ski, kite, and bike.

In 2006, Jeff Somers started a journey around the world on a penny farthing, an old-style bicycle with one large and one small wheel. Before this, he had written a book about his travels in Canada using a 50-year-old car. He was passionate about motor sports and worked on building racing car engines. To save money, Jeff rode an old bicycle to work and even used it for a holiday trip to Amsterdam. ‘That trip opened my eyes,’ he says. ‘I decided to see the world by bike.’ Jeff didn’t want a regular touring bike and wanted to build one himself. ‘The craziest bicycle I could think of was a penny farthing, so I went to the museum to see how they were made.’ After two unsuccessful attempts in 2001 and 2003, when he had to stop due to a knee injury, he finally set off in 2006. He traveled for three years, visiting 23 countries across four continents. The highlight of his trip was reaching Tibet and seeing Mount Everest. ‘Although I met cyclists who could ride up mountains on their bikes, which I couldn’t do, I never regretted my penny farthing. The further away from home I got, the more amazed people seemed by it.’ His worst moment was when he had to drink dirty water from a stream, which led to a serious fever. He was bedridden in a hostel for ten days without medicine. He had no money for hospital bills or to return home. Despite all this, Jeff now says, ‘if I could afford it, I would set off traveling again tomorrow on my penny farthing.’

I work at a university in the US, where my team and I are studying water birds, especially the American black duck. We have just started using a new tool called a 'night-vision scope' that lets us see the ducks in the dark. We are concerned about black ducks because their numbers have dropped a lot, and we are unsure if there is enough food for them on the east coast. We have plenty of information about their daytime activities, but nothing about what they do at night, as we didn't have the right equipment before. This new scope gives us clear pictures, even on nights without moonlight, so we can learn more and make better decisions about protecting their habitat based on our findings. The work is challenging. There are four of us, each working six hours a day. We have studied ducks in various locations, and I have had to take a boat to some sites and record every duck I see. The weather has been difficult – some nights are mild, but more often it's wet. It's so quiet that I need a lot of coffee to stay awake! We've only missed one day of work because the snow was too deep, even for our special snow vehicles. Still, I enjoy the challenge, especially compared to what summer will bring – hours in a lab, where we will analyze our results together. It will be tough to be indoors, but it's necessary. And I wouldn't change it for anything!

Text: 'When I tell people about my job, they can hardly believe it exists. But it's true! I spend my workdays eating chocolate. Tasting chocolate is crucial to ensure that customers receive perfect, high-quality chocolate bars from my company. Every week, I get samples from our factory to check their taste, texture, and smell. I also taste the raw materials we use, like nuts and fruit, and spend time selecting the best ones for our chocolate. Next to my office, I have a kitchen where I test and taste products I create, and I share samples with my colleagues. My kitchen is full of machines and ingredients to experiment with. It's great to have a private space to retreat to during the day. No two days are the same in this job. Sometimes I'm at our food lab, and other times I'm traveling abroad to buy raw materials. This can be challenging because I have a young family. However, I love the variety and lack of routine, although I think the chocolate itself is the best part! People often ask if I get tired of chocolate. I've worked with it for a long time, and I've never felt like I didn't want to eat it. In fact, I often go home and eat more in the evening!'

Have you ever thought about what it's like to perform in a circus? Sophia Grayson is from Circus Experience, a place where young people learn circus skills. Her course is popular because it teaches many skills, like juggling, throwing and catching things such as balls or even fire, and trapeze, which involves flying through the air above an amazed audience. During the year-long course, students gradually take more risks in each class, and parents can attend some classes to see their progress. Sophia explains, "For a circus career, performers need to avoid repeating the same acts – it's important to keep performances exciting and full of action. If you want to succeed in the circus, you must keep practising. Another great aspect is the friendship with other performers and the opportunity to learn from them. Being fit is also crucial – circus artists, like athletes, train daily to stay strong. Training is very important, but the best performers are those who want success, have imagination, and never stop improving their skills. People often think you might get injured or only work a few months each year. But the real challenge is planning for the future because you can only perform while you're young, and then you need to consider other options." The course also includes business planning. Many former students have started businesses worldwide and are happy to share their experiences. Sophia warns, however, that it's not a profession for making money! "The work usually means not having a regular salary. It's also competitive – but great fun!"

You might not know her name or recognize her face, but you've likely heard her voice many times. Mariam Hobson is a professional backing singer, someone who supports the lead singer by singing in the background. Some people think backing singers aren't talented enough to be lead singers. That's not true—they often need to be even more skilled. People like Mariam are the true stars of the music industry! "What I love about my job is that when I enter the recording studio, I never know what I'll be asked to sing," she says. "It could be classical, jazz, hip-hop, or rock. Or it might be a quirky little tune for a radio station or an advertisement. I'm often surprised by producers' requests. Once, I was asked to sing like a fish underwater! But I never argue; I just get on with the job!"

"Excellent musical abilities are essential for my work, along with the ability to learn quickly. There's often no sheet music to refer to. I'll never forget my first experience recording background music for a film. It was very complicated because there were eight of us, each singing a different tune, along with an orchestra. I was terrified: I knew that if I made a mistake, it would mean recording everything again, which nobody enjoys. Recording sessions are long enough as they are."

"One of my favorite jobs is recording for songwriters. Less experienced writers don't always understand which musical range suits the female voice best. By listening to me perform their song, they can figure out how to improve it."

Text: Julie Deane started with only basic fashion knowledge and created a successful business with her 'satchels'—traditional bags used by schoolchildren. These satchels are now sold in world-famous shops and are popular with many celebrities. Before choosing satchels, Julie considered various business ideas, like cake decorating and party planning, instead of going with her first thought. Once she decided, not everyone agreed with her choice. Julie says, "Many said there was no demand for them – but I was convinced." She involved her family from the start, working with her mother, who had never had a career but had a natural business ability. The design inspiration came from children's storybooks. Although Julie didn't know much about fashion blogs, they have been crucial to her success. Initially, she sold about one satchel a week. To generate interest, Julie sent satchels to fashion writers, hoping they would mention them in their blogs. They did, and interest has continued to grow, as has the speed of production. Julie now enjoys seeing which celebrity is pictured with a satchel! While other companies spend money on online advertising, she uses the internet community for ideas for original styles, keeping her products fresh and exciting. There was a challenging time when another company copied Julie's design to sell similar products. As a result, she now ensures she trusts her production team as much as her own staff. Visitors often comment on the positive atmosphere in her offices—people love working there. There's now a new factory, and while buildings are important, it's the team that makes it a special place.

When Vicky Harmiston was a child, her parents let her and her brother Jamie choose how to spend their free time. Vicky decided to try many sports. She was a talented swimmer, and her coach thought she could become a champion. However, the swimming club was far from her home, making it hard to balance training with schoolwork. As teenagers, Jamie, who loved cycling, bought a special racing bike and started competing. Vicky found it exciting and decided to try cycling too. She says it was the best decision she ever made. Soon, she was cycling daily and performing well. The track was close to her school, so she could easily attend training sessions after school. Vicky had a successful career in track cycling and won several competitions. At 28, she retired from competitive cycling. Vicky said, ‘I loved winning competitions for years, but I started to feel tired of it all – and when the excitement fades, there’s no point. Fortunately, I found a new career.’ Vicky got a job with a charity called CycleZone. ‘We work with young people who have never enjoyed sport,’ she says. ‘First, we teach them to ride a bike. We want them to believe in themselves and their abilities. CycleZone does a great job, bringing young people together as part of a larger group.’ The charity uses celebrities to promote their work. Vicky says, ‘Some people doubt whether celebrity support is always good for a charity. They think celebrities do it for self-promotion, which can overshadow the charity’s real work. But if famous singers and actors can help, I think they should.’

Singer-songwriter Ana Ronson grew up in Ireland. Her parents weren't musicians, but there was always music at home. Her grandfather played the guitar and taught Ana and her brother. Ana first sang in front of an audience at school. She was so nervous that her teacher had to help her off the stage. The teacher suggested she join the school theatre club to gain confidence.
