After some time in the club, she sang with 50 other students at a concert. A year later, her brother, who was in a band, asked her to write a song. She wrote her first song, Falling Stars, in just three days. She enjoyed it so much that she joined a songwriting course taught by a professional. Although she was the youngest, she knew more about music than many others. However, Ana felt the teacher ignored her ideas, so she wrote Something to Say about her frustration. She posted the song online, and it became very popular. People loved it and found new meanings in the lyrics each time they listened. Joss Alton, who owns a recording company called Isotope Music, traveled across Ireland to invite her to join Isotope. At first, Ana was unsure because she didn't know the company and didn't want to be told what to sing. Joss assured her this wouldn't happen, and soon she performed at a concert in Dublin organized by Isotope. The tickets sold out quickly, and it was an amazing night. Ana prefers writing songs about difficult times because she feels there's more to express. One of her favorite songs is Decision, about why her brother stopped singing for a while and how it affected him. While she hopes fans enjoy her songs, her goal is to write about personal experiences that matter to her.

Last year, I went on an incredible trip—a guided group tour by boat along Canada's west coast. It was my brother Harry's idea. Like me, he's a journalist, and he wanted to write articles about the trip. He's a big fan of boats, which is not something we have in common. However, I had always dreamed of visiting the area since seeing it on TV as a child, especially because our great-grandparents lived there before moving to Europe. So, I kept asking Harry if I could join him until he finally agreed! A few days before our departure, there were storms in the area we planned to visit. Fortunately, the weather forecast for our trip promised calm seas. Although there was a lot to organize, I was busy with work and didn't have much time to think about it. But Harry assured me he had taken care of everything, so I stopped worrying. After arriving in Canada, we joined the group, packed our limited supplies into small boats, and set off. The guide mentioned that very few people lived along that coast, and indeed, the only other living creatures we saw that first morning were dolphins and birds. We knew there were islands in the distance, but the early-morning fog made it hard to see far, so I focused on the beautiful patterns our boat made in the water. We often stopped for hours to explore the rock pools on the beaches along the coast. They were full of amazing colored fish, many of which I didn't recognize. It was wonderful to stop worrying about how quickly or slowly the day was passing. We never forgot lunch or dinner, which we all prepared together over campfires. When we finally fell asleep on the boats each evening, even though the beds were hard, it truly felt like stress-free living! When it was time to leave, I felt sad. How could I return to normal life? But I knew if I stayed, I would miss family and friends. I was also excited to tell everyone at home about our adventures!

My dad was a professional basketball player in Germany, just like his father before him. As a child, I often went to watch his games. You might think that seeing so many matches would make me love basketball, but it actually did the opposite. I enjoyed telling my friends how good my dad was, especially when he won, but I usually brought a book to read instead of watching the games. When I started secondary school, I was not yet a teenager but was already two meters tall. My sports teacher noticed my height and asked if I wanted to train with the basketball team. I enjoyed the training session but felt I needed to improve my skills before playing in a real match. However, my teacher believed in me more than I did. It took some time, but a few weeks later, I played against another school. Having my parents watch made me nervous, but it turned out fine! For the next four years, I practiced daily and did well, even joining an adult team before moving to a special sports academy in the USA at fifteen. The coach there trains Olympic players, and it was amazing to work with him. However, I didn't enjoy being far from my parents at first. At home, I couldn't spend much time with friends because of training, so that part didn't change much. Eventually, I got used to my new life, and my English improved quickly! I turned professional at eighteen, three years after arriving in the USA. I had been taller than most professional players since I was fifteen but was too light for my height, so I had to work on that first. My coach knew a team that would take me while I was still in college, so I joined them and have never regretted it.

Seven years ago, I was studying Tourism at college and needed a part-time job because my course was expensive. After considering several options, I trained to become a weekend tour guide in my home city, Chicago, USA. This involved taking visitors around the city, and I was surprised by how much I enjoyed it. I got to see the city I’d lived in my whole life through the eyes of tourists, and it felt new every time! After finishing my studies, I decided to become a full-time tour guide. Although I thought it would be simple, I found out that to get a licence, I needed to know much more than I had learned. Chicago guides must answer many questions about the city, covering everything from local architecture and history to public transport rules. After several challenging but interesting months, I gained my tour guide qualification and registered as an independent tour guide. Tour guiding isn’t just about knowing historical facts or keeping track of your group in crowds. Many other skills are necessary. You should be entertaining and tell interesting stories, and you need to react to changing situations, like if a place is closed when you arrive or a route changes. Tourists don’t want to hear about problems; they just want to enjoy a well-organised tour. I need to ensure visitors are happy with my tours, or they might post a negative review online. Like most tour guides, I know these reviews are important because good reviews attract more customers. That’s why making tours fun and stress-free is essential. My enthusiasm and energy mean my reviews are usually very good, and my tours are often recommended to other visitors coming to Chicago.

My name is Ella, and I am 22 years old. Last year, I traveled to Thailand for two weeks with my sister, Josie. Although she is five years younger than me, we get along quite well. We went to volunteer at an elephant sanctuary, a place where people care for sick and rescued elephants. Initially, I was unsure if we would connect with the other volunteers because they were much older than us. We were also nervous since it was our first experience doing something like this. However, there was no need to worry in the end.

One of our main tasks at the sanctuary was to gather food for the elephants. Elephants consume large amounts of grass and banana plants, so collecting this took most of the day. Josie found it challenging, but seeing the elephants enjoy their meals made it worthwhile for me. We also helped wash the elephants in the river using big brushes and soap. I found this very enjoyable, even though I ended up wetter than the elephants!

The part of the day I looked forward to the most was the evening. By moonlight, we led the elephants on foot into the forest area where they spent the night. All the volunteers stayed in the same house. Josie and I shared a bedroom, so space was limited. That was our choice, as Josie preferred not to be alone. It was hot and humid, especially at night, but we expected that. The meals were delicious and vegetarian, which suited us since we are not fond of meat. After dinner, all the volunteers and staff spent the evenings talking and playing games.

Now that we are back in the UK, Josie rarely talks about Thailand. But if someone asks her if she enjoyed her time at the sanctuary, she says she loved it. However, I am not sure she is being completely honest. I think she might be a bit upset with herself for not fully enjoying her time there because she missed her friends too much. But when she reflects on it, she realizes how fortunate she was to have the experience. Maybe she will return one day—I certainly plan to!

I'm Gina D’Costa, and I own a flower shop in the UK. We don't just sell flowers to people for their friends or homes; we have a variety of customers. Hotels and offices often have flowers in their reception areas, and sometimes we provide flowers for business photo shoots. Once, I even decorated a castle with flowers for a wedding. It was a lot of work, but I was really proud of it. My day starts at 4 a.m. when I go to the market to buy fresh flowers. Most people are still asleep then, and my friends think I'm crazy, but I love what I do. It's often colder and darker than I'd like, but that's normal for that time of the morning, so I don't mind. The flower market is amazing, with flowers from all over the world. The sights and smells make choosing difficult. If I were choosing for myself, I'd probably only pick pink ones because it's my favorite color. But I have to remember that what I like and what customers want aren't always the same. Not all flowers are available year-round, so sometimes I can't find what customers want. I don't enjoy negotiating prices with the flower sellers, but it's necessary. Flowers aren't cheap, so I try to get the best price. Back at the shop, we check customer orders and arrange the flowers I bought. Then we create bouquets and calculate the cost of orders. Customers are often surprised by the prices, and I sometimes have to ask them to reconsider their choices. Some might think this is too much trouble, but I enjoy figuring out how to make the nicest arrangements for the money they want to spend. That's part of selling things, and I wouldn't want any other job!

My city has a modern cinema that shows all the latest films, including many for kids on weekends. It's close to where I live, but a year ago, I felt something was missing—the chance to discuss a film in detail with others after watching it. So, with two friends, I started a film club! We decided not to rent a cinema for our screenings. Instead, we pick a different location in the city each month. For instance, we rented an old factory to show a film set in Antarctica. It was very cold, which created the perfect atmosphere for the film—it was amazing! Some venues are even free because the owners earn money by selling snacks during the film, allowing us to keep our prices low. We’re happy just to cover our costs—we’re not aiming for profit. Each screening gets easier, especially now that we have our own reliable equipment. We also track ticket sales online, so we no longer worry about empty seats! There’s always plenty to do, but when people of all ages tell us they had a great experience, it’s wonderful. Our website has been a great help, and we’re now in touch with other film clubs across the country. We’ve visited them to see how they operate, but it’s always nice to return to our own club! We’ve started a blog, too, because most people now look online for film information rather than reading local paper reviews. We’ve also tried putting up posters in cafés. However, nothing beats word of mouth—people recommending us to their friends. The audience loves the special activities we organize with each film—last month, we had a movie quiz that everyone enjoyed.

Text: 'As a child, taking photographs was my favorite activity. When I was 15, I wanted to take my hobby further, so I decided to start a personal project: taking one photograph every day for a year. Many young photographers had done this before, but it seemed like a great idea to me, so I began. After a few weeks, I uploaded these photos to a website for young photographers to create a photo diary and share my work. I was surprised to find that others liked my perspective and photography. I enjoyed capturing a variety of subjects. Someone suggested that having a common theme would improve my project, and I agreed. I started focusing on nature scenes, especially birds and the sky. Many of my photos were black and white, unlike other young photographers who used color. I sometimes doubted my project and almost quit several times. However, I trusted my instincts and grew more confident in my style. I showed my project to my art teacher, who told me about a national photography competition for people my age. I entered some photos for fun. I'll never forget when the judges announced I had won first prize; I was thrilled because my project was important to me. It was the first time I realized my photography might be good enough for a professional career. Now, I have my own photography studio and have never regretted my career choice.'

I joined the National Youth Challenge (NYC) last year because they offered activities like camping, sailing, and public speaking, which I had never tried before. In the NYC, you can participate in various activities to challenge yourself and learn new things. There are different levels, from beginner to advanced, led by adult volunteers called 'leaders'. When you complete each level, you receive a certificate. When I first joined, my leader suggested that my initial challenge should be helping to organize activities at a local children’s club for two hours a week. I was unsure about this idea because I had joined that club when I was eight and found it hard to make friends. I was quite shy, and the other children already had their own groups, so I stopped going after a few weeks. However, I decided to take on the challenge because I wanted my first NYC certificate. Soon, I wanted to spend all my free time at the children’s club. It became more important to me than just earning the certificate. After completing the challenge, the NYC leader allowed me to continue volunteering at the club because I had developed strong relationships with the children. Now, I volunteer there for about four hours a week and always look forward to it. Because of my experience at the children’s club, I have decided that when I finish school in three years, I want to go to college to become a qualified youth worker, someone who works with children. This was not something I had considered before joining the club. In fact, I had never thought about my future career, and youth work had never crossed my mind. This has been my favorite part of the NYC so far, and I have improved my communication skills while helping others. I have earned several other NYC certificates now, including one for camping!

I was born in Denver, USA, and started snowboarding when I was eight. My dad took me to a mountain resort about two hours from Denver. The hill looked very steep, so my dad had to convince me to try snowboarding. I was young and hadn't thought about snowboarding, but my dad loved it and wanted me to enjoy it too. He made it look easy, and eventually, I managed well. After that, I quickly developed a love for the sport and improved my skills. I started competing at ten. Some people enter many competitions and get bored, but my love for competing and winning has grown stronger as I've gotten older, which motivates me to push myself. I like not having a fixed plan, and sometimes it works out well, like when I became the first female to score a perfect 100 at a local competition. I wasn't sure I'd try the jumps that got me this score until I started. That achievement boosted my confidence in my abilities. In the summer, I focus on training and studying since there's no snow. I train daily, but it's nice not to follow a strict diet like in winter. I also spend a lot of time with friends, which helps me cope with not being able to snowboard. I have to think about my future. Snowboarding is a big part of my life, but I feel it's important to have another option in case I don't succeed as a professional snowboarder or if I get injured. I'm considering becoming a doctor if my active life allows time for college. It's hard to imagine getting tired of snowboarding, but I can't do it my whole life.

When I was fifteen, I wanted everything my friends had and never thought about the future. For instance, I didn't know what I wanted to do after school. One day, my best friend got a new phone for her birthday, and I wanted one too. My parents said I could have it only if I paid for it myself, so I decided to work part-time and save money. I am grateful to my parents for this because it taught me an important lesson. I worked every Saturday in a café, but I didn't enjoy it much. My parents suggested I start my own small business instead. I had seen my mum making necklaces, so I asked if I could try it. I was surprised at how easy it was, even though it looked complicated when I watched Mum. My friends thought it was boring, but I was excited about it. Mum showed me how to create something nice at home with simple tools and materials. I sold my first pieces of jewellery to friends and family, who said they loved them. I thought they were just being nice, so I wasn't sure if they were good enough for the public. To find out, I rented a market stall with my mum. Many tourists visit my town, and they bought my jewellery as gifts. Soon, we got calls from all over the country from people wanting to buy more. They thought we were a big company, but it was just the two of us at a market stall! That's when I realized it could work, and I decided to create a website. Since then, I've made thousands of pounds through my business, mostly online, but we still have our stall too. It's been a lot of fun so far.

When Janine Stuart was just 13, she wrote a novel called Being Amelia, which became a bestseller. The book is partly inspired by Janine’s own life. In an interview, Janine explained, "Because of my father’s job, my family moved around a lot, so I got good at making new friends. I know what it’s like to be the new student in a class, and that helped me write about Amelia, the main character, starting at a new school. Some of the funniest parts of the book are about Amelia’s home life, especially her relationship with her older brother. Since I’m an only child, I had to use my imagination for that." Janine began writing her novel one summer when she was bored at home. Her mother had always dreamed of being a published author, and her teachers encouraged her to write, so it seemed natural for Janine to start writing. The year before, she had won first prize in a short story competition on a young writers’ website. Because of this, when Janine finished Being Amelia and sent it to a publisher, they were eager to read it. They loved it, and a year later, Janine’s novel was available in bookshops. One review of Being Amelia notes that, despite the cover showing happy teenagers, the characters face some tough challenges, which makes them believable. The reviewer says that even though Janine is young and the novel isn’t very long, she has shown she is a better writer than many bestselling authors. Janine is still getting used to being a famous writer: "At first, I hid when people recognized me in the street, but now it’s OK. I’d like to give advice to other young writers, but they need to find what works for them. For me, spending time with friends gives me ideas to write about!"

I'm Tom, I'm fifteen, and three years ago my family and I moved to a castle on a small island. This happened because my father was invited to manage the castle. He works for an organization that takes care of historical buildings and keeps them open to the public. He was excited about the opportunity, but it took some time for the rest of us to agree he should take the job. We were concerned about what life on the island would be like. We knew the castle might not be as comfortable as our cozy home across the water, and there was no school on the island. However, once we moved, we quickly adapted to island life. The castle isn't particularly beautiful, but our apartment in it is comfortable. In summer, the island feels lively because it attracts many visitors, and there are often beach parties. In winter, we only see the other families living on the island, and there aren't as many teenagers as I had hoped. The adults support each other and help with repairs, which often involves hard work. The biggest change for me was traveling by boat every day to my old school. I was excited about stormy days with big waves, but the ferries don't run then! I've learned that if I miss the bus to the harbor after school, I miss the last ferry home, which is worrying. So when schoolmates visit, I always tell them to hurry up! But we often get fantastic views, like when the sun sets over the sea. Some days, it's so foggy you can't see anything, then suddenly it's sunny again – it's still amazing even after living here for a while. Of course, we do get terrible storms, and I sometimes wonder if the castle is strong enough to avoid damage. But then I remind myself it's been here for centuries – and it's still standing!

I live in a house surrounded by beautiful countryside in Scotland. I’ve always loved nature and wild animals, and six years ago, I started a new hobby – birdwatching! I went to some mountains in northern Scotland with my family, where we saw many birds in their natural environment. I spent hours watching them with my parents, who taught me how to tell different species apart and find the best places to see them. It was amazing, and after returning home, I joined a local young birdwatchers’ club. My goal is to see 200 different bird species, and I’m close to achieving that because on family holidays abroad, I’ve seen birds from other countries too. We always look for places with group birdwatching activities, so I can add new birds to my list! I’ve been to Egypt, and last summer we went to South America, where I thought I’d see my 200th species. I wasn’t too disappointed when it didn’t happen, though, as I’ve learned that patience is important in this hobby. I posted a video online about this challenge, and many teenagers found it fascinating and commented on it. When my teachers saw it, they asked me to give a presentation about birdwatching at school. I didn’t feel nervous until just before I was introduced and walked onto the stage. I knew I’d remember what to say and had some notes to help me, but the whole school and all my friends were watching me! I only relaxed when it was over, and the teachers said I’d prepared well and they’d really enjoyed it. I might even do another one next year! I’m lucky to live in the countryside. I understand why many teenagers in cities might not think of becoming birdwatchers, but there are actually plenty of birds to see, especially in places with lots of green areas. I also think that birdwatching clubs should try to get more young people interested in this hobby. Everyone needs to connect with nature, whatever their age, and it doesn’t have to cost much money.

I began playing football at the age of 7. I would hurry home from school to play with other kids. I loved it, and soon I became a decent player. However, my family knew I often got excited about new hobbies and then lost interest, so they probably thought the same would happen with football. But it didn’t. In fact, I was already dreaming of playing football professionally when I grew up. The chance came sooner than I expected. I often played in local tournaments, and one referee noticed my potential. He asked the manager of a professional women’s club to watch me play. She was impressed and invited me to join her club. I couldn’t believe it at first – I didn’t know young girls could join women’s clubs. But I started regular training with a big club at just 13 years old. After that, I improved a lot. Despite this, some people doubted I’d become a star player, which upset me a bit. But the coach encouraged me to be myself and believe in myself – he even let me play in one of the club’s championship matches earlier than I expected! I’ve never run so hard in my life – I didn’t want the other players to blame me for losing. Then, by pure luck, I scored the winning goal. Despite the large crowd, I could clearly hear my coach cheering me on, and after the match, the team carried me around the pitch. It was fantastic! Since then, I’ve scored many more winning goals! Next month, my coach and I are organizing a football tournament in my area. The goal is to get teenagers interested in football and give them a chance to talk to other players in my club. It will show them the professional environment and encourage them to believe they could play for a top team if they work hard. My advice to them will be the same as my coach’s advice to me – you’ll have good times, but be ready for bad times too. I’ve had very few of those, though – so I’ve been lucky!

One of the most interesting changes in higher education in the UK and worldwide is encouraging students to engage in research early in their studies. This shift acknowledges that research is not just for famous scholars or scientists at top universities. Instead, it is a fundamental way to build knowledge and skills. Research skills are valuable not only in academics but also in the workplace, as they help us think critically about the world and our work. As a student, you contribute to knowledge by asking questions like Why? How? When? What does this mean? How might that be done? What if this were different? How does it work in that context? Why does it matter? These questions are at the heart of research.

Research can range from groundbreaking, complex studies by highly trained experts to everyday inquiries that involve careful work and thoughtful questions about issues and practices. Most students have been researchers in some way, asking questions and investigating since their early days in school or work. You have developed research skills when planning a holiday, growing plants, fixing things, training a pet, choosing a music system, or shopping online.

In college and higher education, having an enquiring mind, identifying problems, critically evaluating information, and constructing your own responses are expected learning activities. Some students may find this challenging, especially if they come from cultures where knowledge is seen as established and learned by listening to authority figures like teachers and texts. In the UK, US, much of Europe, and Australasia, questioning established knowledge and authorities is encouraged. This approach might seem daunting, but critical thinking is crucial in research. We must engage with others' research, test it, and determine if it is logical and backed by evidence, rather than accepting it uncritically.

Cities have always been centers of intellectual activity. In the 18th century, London coffee houses were places where people discussed topics like chemistry and politics. In modern Paris, cafés on the Left Bank were where artist Pablo Picasso talked about modern art. However, living in a city is not always easy. Those same London coffee houses also spread diseases like cholera, and Picasso eventually moved to the countryside. While cities can be creative hubs, they are also unnatural and overwhelming. Scientists are now studying how city life affects our brains, and the findings are concerning. Although city life is known to be tiring, new research shows that it can also dull our thinking. One major factor is the lack of nature, which is surprisingly good for the brain. Studies show that hospital patients recover faster when they can see trees from their windows. Even brief views of nature can improve brain function because they offer a mental break from city life. This research is timely, as more people now live in cities than ever before. Instead of open spaces, we live in crowded urban areas, surrounded by strangers. These unnatural environments impact our mental and physical health and change how we think. Walking down a busy city street requires the brain to manage many tasks: avoiding distracted pedestrians, crossing streets safely, and navigating the complex layout. These tasks drain our mental energy because they force us to constantly focus and redirect our attention. The brain is like a powerful computer, but paying attention uses a lot of its resources. In contrast, natural settings don't demand as much cognitive effort. This concept is called attention restoration theory, developed by psychologist Stephen Kaplan. He suggested that being in nature can restore our attention. Natural environments capture our attention without causing negative emotions, unlike city noises like police sirens. This allows our mental focus to relax and recharge. Long before scientists studied this, philosophers and landscape architects warned about the effects of city life and sought ways to incorporate nature into urban areas. Parks like Central Park in New York offer an escape from city life and can quickly improve brain function. While people try various methods to boost cognitive performance, such as energy drinks or office redesigns, few are as effective as a walk in nature. Despite the mental challenges of city life, cities continue to grow. Even in the digital age, they remain sources of intellectual life. Research from the Santa Fe Institute shows that the same urban features that challenge our attention also drive innovation. The concentration of social interactions in cities fuels creativity. Just as 18th-century London was a hub of intellectual breakthroughs, modern cities like Cambridge, Massachusetts, thrive as centers of technology. Less crowded cities may produce less innovation over time. The challenge is to reduce the psychological harm of city life while keeping its benefits. As the saying goes, sometimes people feel, "I'm sick of the trees, take me to the city!"

Text: 'Where should we look for the mind? It might seem obvious: thinking happens inside our heads. Today, we have advanced brain imaging to support this. However, I believe the study of the mind shouldn't stop at the skin or skull. Evidence from prehistory to now shows that objects, not just neurons, are part of human thinking. Archaeology reveals that stone tools, ornaments, engravings, clay tokens, and writing systems have influenced human evolution and the mind. So, what is outside the head might still be part of the mind. The mind and brain are often seen as the same because studies usually isolate people from their surroundings to focus on the brain. This is practical for neuroscientists using brain scans, but it overlooks how much thinking happens outside our heads. I don't deny the brain's role in cognition, but I suggest that human intelligence extends into culture and the material world. This idea is central to my Material Engagement Theory (MET). MET explores how objects become part of our thinking, like using clay for numbers or stones for tools. It also looks at how these interactions have evolved and what they mean for our thinking. This approach changes our understanding of the mind by considering what objects do for it. Consider a blind person with a stick. Where does their self begin? The stick and the person form a unit, showing how minds and objects are connected. The stick helps the blind person 'see' through touch, becoming part of their body. This example highlights the adaptability of human intelligence, which changes with new technologies. I see the human mind as always evolving. Throughout history, from stone tools to the internet, objects have been pathways for understanding the world, not barriers. Humans use 'sticks' to explore and learn, unlike monkeys who use them just for food. This unique human trait explains why we create things and how these things shape our minds. I call this metaplasticity—our minds change as they interact with the material world. MET offers a new perspective on how material culture, from ancient tools to smartphones, shapes and transforms our thinking. While 'mind-changing technology' sounds futuristic, humans have used it since our beginnings.'

Few inventions have changed civilization as much as photography. This is especially true in the United States, where photography quickly became part of the culture at every level—from practical and scientific uses to industrial and aesthetic ones, and even entertainment. Historians argue that photography is perhaps the greatest contribution of the US to the visual arts. In no other art form has US work been so influential. This suggests that photography is central to US intellectual and aesthetic discussions, and to fully appreciate its impact, we must look at its beginnings in the mid-19th century.

Why was photography so appealing? Firstly, it was a mechanical process that matched the growing enthusiasm for technology in a country that embraced change. Just as steam power, railroads, and electricity made the world smaller by improving communication and travel, photography brought the wonders of the world into people's homes with stunning immediacy. Secondly, the camera was the preferred tool for representing oneself, allowing people to present an image for public view in a country where personal and national identities were always evolving. Thirdly, the camera was important for creating and preserving family memories, even if they were somewhat idealized. Finally, the realism of photographs matched the US artists' tendency towards realism and depicting everyday life.

A photograph draws attention to something, showing what the photographer wants us to see. Because it is made by a machine, a photograph is a record of events, people, or things, and it has a certain objectivity. However, since it is taken by an individual, it also carries a personal perspective, or subjectivity. We might think we understand a photograph because we recognize the subject, leading to the idea of photography as a 'universal language.' But photographic meaning is more complex. No image is presented without some context that influences our understanding, such as a newspaper caption or its placement in a gallery. To understand a photograph historically, we need to consider its purpose and function in its cultural context: Why did the photographer take it? How was it first seen? The same image might be viewed in different places and times, changing its meaning each time.

The camera's importance to artists was once a secret, but now it is widely recognized. For several decades, starting with US artist Andy Warhol's use of photographs in paintings and silk screens, artists have been incorporating photographs into their work in various ways. In short, photographic vision has become an essential part of art history, not opposing painting but complementing it, and is integral to our ideas of representation before the camera was invented.

In 1890, William James, an American philosopher and one of the founders of modern psychology, described psychology as the "science of mental life." This definition is still useful today. We all have a mental life, so we have some understanding of what this means. However, even though we can study this concept in animals like rats and monkeys, it remains somewhat elusive. James, like most psychologists, was particularly interested in human psychology. He believed it consisted of basic elements: thoughts and feelings, a physical world in time and space, and a way of knowing about these things. This knowledge is mainly personal and private, coming from our own thoughts, feelings, and experiences. It may or may not be influenced by scientific facts. Because of this, we often make judgments about psychological matters based on our own experiences. We act as amateur psychologists when we give opinions on complex psychological issues, like whether brainwashing works, or when we state our opinions as facts about why people behave in certain ways, such as feeling insulted or unhappy, or suddenly quitting their jobs. Problems arise when two people understand things differently. Formal psychology tries to provide methods to decide which explanations are most likely correct in a given situation or to determine when each applies. Psychologists help us distinguish between subjective thoughts, which may be biased, and facts: between our preconceptions and what is scientifically "true." Psychology, as defined by James, is about the mind or brain. Although psychologists study the brain, they do not fully understand its workings to explain its role in our hopes, fears, and wishes, or in our behavior during different experiences like giving birth or watching a football match. It is rarely possible to study the brain directly. So, psychologists learn more by studying behavior and using observations to form hypotheses about what is happening inside us. A challenge in psychology is that scientific facts should be objective and verifiable, but the mind's workings are not observable like an engine's. In everyday life, they can only be perceived indirectly and inferred from behavior. Psychology is like solving a crossword puzzle, involving evaluating and interpreting clues. These clues must come from careful observation, accurate measurement, scientific analysis, and logical interpretation that can be publicly scrutinized. Complex interactions are common in psychology, and understanding them requires sophisticated techniques and theories. Psychology aims to describe, understand, predict, and learn how to control or modify the processes it studies. Once these goals are achieved, it can help us understand our experiences and apply conclusions to people's lives. Psychological findings have been useful in areas like teaching children to read, designing safer machine control panels, and helping emotionally distressed people communicate their feelings better. Although psychological questions have been discussed for centuries, they have only been scientifically investigated in the past 150 years. Early psychologists used introspection—reflecting on one's own conscious experience—to answer psychological questions. These early studies aimed to identify mental structures, which is still of interest today. However, introspection has limitations. As Sir Francis Galton noted, it leaves one a helpless spectator of only a small part of automatic brain work. William James compared trying to understand the mind through introspection to "turning up the gas quickly enough to see how the darkness looks." Modern psychologists prefer to base their theories on careful observations of phenomena, like others' behavior, rather than on personal reflections.

In a warehouse in a business park in Michigan, USA, there is a unique collection known as the Museum of Failed Products. This museum, owned by a company called GfK, displays products that were removed from sale because they were unpopular, like A Touch of Yogurt shampoo and Breakfast Cola. Carol Sherry, who manages the museum, believes each product tells a sad story of failure for its creators. Surprisingly, the museum is a successful business, attracting executives who rarely keep their own failed products. The museum began by accident when Robert McMath, a former marketing professional, started collecting new products in the 1960s. He wanted a 'reference library' of consumer products, not just failures. However, he discovered that most products fail, so his collection naturally included many unsuccessful items.

Today's culture of optimism might explain why these failed products exist. Many products likely passed through meetings where no one realized they were doomed. Even if they did, marketers might have invested more money to force some sales and save face. Little effort is made to understand what went wrong, and people involved often avoid discussing failures. This focus on optimism is common in the growing 'self-help' industry, where 'positive visualization' is popular. The idea is that imagining success makes it more likely, but neuroscientist Tali Sharot suggests our brains are wired to be overly optimistic. Her research shows that well-balanced people often overestimate their ability to influence events, unlike those with depression.

Psychologist Gabriele Oettingen has studied the effects of 'positive fantasies about the future.' Her findings reveal that thinking too much about success can reduce motivation. For example, people encouraged to imagine a successful week at work often achieve less. Psychologist Carol Dweck explains that our response to failure depends on our beliefs about ability. People with a 'fixed theory' mindset think ability is innate, so failure is terrifying. In contrast, those with an 'incremental theory' believe ability grows through effort and see failure as a chance to improve. Dweck compares this to weight-training: muscles grow by being pushed to their limits. Having an incremental mindset is a happier way to live, regardless of success.

Text: 'Everyone knows that sports teams have a big advantage when they play at home. But why is that? Many of us think we know; it seems obvious. However, professional sports are changing quickly, and what we used to believe is now being questioned. Two main factors challenge the traditional idea of home advantage: science and money. Sports scientists want to understand what makes players perform at their best, leading to many theories about home advantage. Meanwhile, financial interests question if home advantage should matter at all. If players are paid well, shouldn't they perform well anywhere? 

What about the fans? Would it matter if Manchester United played some home games in the Far East to reach their fans there? It would matter to British fans, who believe their team needs their passion and support. Fans often think that their cheering leads to goals, but they forget the times when their noise didn't lead to success. 

However, one fan belief is supported by science. Home fans often try to influence the referee. In a famous experiment, referees watched a match with and without crowd noise. Those who heard the noise were less likely to call fouls against the home team. This matched the actual decisions made during the game. Researchers concluded that referees avoid extra stress by not making calls against the home team. 

Recent studies show that home advantage has decreased in all major sports, but not as much as expected. For example, in the 1890s, home teams in England's Football League won about 70% of the points, compared to 60% today. Travel used to be difficult, but now players travel in luxury. Stadiums are also more similar now. Despite these changes, home advantage still varies by sport. 

Basketball has the most home advantage, followed by football. Baseball has the least. One reason might be that home advantage is more about team spirit, which is less important in baseball. Team sports require coordination, and playing at home boosts confidence. 

Another possibility is related to a primitive urge to defend home territory. Studies show players' testosterone levels are higher before home games. This was seen in the Rugby World Cup, where underdogs won at home using determination and aggression. As one referee said, ‘It’s the law of the jungle out there.’"

Text: "‘The more I practise, the luckier I get,’ said golfer Gary Player about fifty years ago. This saying is famous in sports and valued by athletes and coaches. The quote's origin is debated, with claims for other golfers of that time. Its meaning is also intriguing. Player didn't mean luck literally; he was speaking ironically. His real message was: ‘The more I practise, the better I get.’ But how much better can one get through practice alone? This question is central to the nature-nurture debate in sports: is talent innate or developed? The discussion has been one-sided, favoring nurture. The idea that practice is more important than natural talent in any field is linked to psychologist Anders Ericsson. He proposed that 10,000 hours of practice can make anyone an expert. This theory inspired books like Malcolm Gladwell’s "Outliers" and others, all suggesting practice is key. They argue that 10,000 hours is necessary and sufficient for expertise. However, in his book, Epstein challenges this view with many case studies. He points out a flaw in research on excellence: it often only looks at successful people. Science is better at explaining why an elite athlete succeeds after the fact. Epstein explores why some people have certain abilities and others don't, considering innate traits and factors like environment and determination. His research takes him worldwide, from Kenya to Sweden, and even to Alaska. There, he learns that in a tough sled dog race, the huskies' drive might be genetic, suggesting a link between genes and motivation. This challenges the idea that commitment is purely a choice. Epstein distinguishes between 'hardware' (nature) and 'software' (nurture) and believes both are essential for elite athletes. He acknowledges the role of training and environment, suggesting that if Usain Bolt had grown up in the US, he might have been a basketball player instead of a sprinter. But Epstein also highlights cases where genetics are crucial. He examines race and gender issues, asking: ‘If only practice matters, why separate men and women in sports?’ Sometimes, the simplest questions are the most insightful."

A recent international report shows that many children in wealthy countries feel lonely and unhappy. Jay Griffiths asks why this is happening. In her book, "Kith," she suggests that children are spending too much time indoors, stuck in front of screens, and have lost touch with nature. This, she argues, is the main issue. This idea aligns with other discussions about modern childhood. A follow-up study interviewed children and found that many would be happier if they could spend more time outside. Many adults over 40 remember their own childhoods fondly, recalling days spent exploring outdoors, which they believe was healthier than the sheltered lives of today's children. However, these adults often forget that they are the ones who have created this protective environment for their children, avoiding risks like playing in old sheds.

Griffiths' book contains strong arguments. She discusses the fear of outdoor dangers and how it benefits the toy and gadget industry, which sells products to keep children entertained indoors. She also criticizes trends like prescribing medication for restless children or making them wear goggles for playground games. While it's unclear how common these practices are, Griffiths expresses her frustration effectively. She is also inspiring when discussing childhood freedoms and restrictions, from fairy tales to school rules. However, Griffiths sometimes takes her ideas too far, ignoring important counter-arguments. At one point, she even compares modern treatment of children to a form of racism, which seems exaggerated.

Griffiths is a romantic when it comes to children. She mostly sees them in an idealized way, which might not hold up in real life. She believes children should have the freedom to explore and take risks, arguing that they need small accidents to learn how to avoid bigger ones. However, she doesn't explain how to ensure these accidents are "the right size." Also, not all children may want the adventurous life she describes. What about those who are naturally timid or prefer staying indoors? Perhaps the real mistake is forcing all children into the same mold, whether keeping them inside or pushing them outside.

I'm a research bio-psychologist with a PhD, so I've spent a lot of time in school. I'm good at solving problems, both at work and in life, but this isn't because of my schooling. Most life problems can't be solved with complex formulas or memorized answers from school. They need judgment, wisdom, and creativity, which come from life experiences. For children, these experiences are found in play. My recent research focuses on the importance of play for children's development. All mammals, including humans, play when they are young, and those with more to learn play the most. Carnivores play more than herbivores because hunting is harder to learn than grazing. Primates play more than other mammals because their lives depend more on learning than on instincts. Children, who have the most to learn, play more than any other young primates when they can. Play is how adults and mammals have always educated themselves. The most important skills for children to learn for a happy, productive, moral life can't be taught in school. These skills are learned and practiced through play. They include creativity, getting along with others, cooperating, and controlling impulses and emotions. Creativity is crucial for economic success. We don't need people to follow instructions like robots or do routine calculations. We need people who can ask new questions and solve new problems. If we can develop thinkers who anticipate obstacles, we'll have a strong workforce. This requires creative thinking. A creative mind is a playful mind. Geniuses are those who keep and build on their childlike creativity. Albert Einstein said school almost destroyed his interest in math and physics, but he regained it after leaving school. He called his innovative work 'combinatorial play.' He developed his theory of relativity by imagining himself chasing a sunbeam and catching it, then thinking about the consequences. We can't teach creativity, but we can suppress it with schooling focused on imposed questions with one right answer. More important than creativity is the ability to get along with others, care for them, and cooperate. Children are born wanting to play with others, and through play, they learn social skills, fairness, and morality. Play is voluntary, meaning players can quit anytime. If you can't quit, it's not play. Players know they must keep others happy to continue the game. This makes play the most democratic activity. School has become more demanding: breaks are shorter, homework has increased, and pressure for high grades has grown. Outside school, adult-directed sports have replaced spontaneous games. 'Play dates' with adults present have replaced unsupervised neighborhood play, and adults now feel they must intervene rather than let children solve their own problems. These changes have been gradual but significant over time. They result from social factors like parents' fears, experts warning about dangers, declining neighborhood cohesion, and the belief that children learn more from adults than from each other. Our children don't need more school; they need more play. If we care about our children and future generations, we must reverse the trend of the past fifty years. We must give childhood back to children. They must be allowed to follow their natural drive to play and explore, so they can grow into strong adults ready for an unpredictable future.

In many countries, more people in their twenties are using social media to find jobs. Platforms like Twitter and LinkedIn allow direct contact with potential employers, similar to standing outside an office with a "hire me" sign. However, this access also increases the risk of mistakes. For example, a young jobseeker in the US reached out to a senior marketing executive on LinkedIn, hoping to access her influential contacts. The executive, offended by the request, not only declined but also sent a sarcastic rejection note that went viral. This incident highlights the importance of using social media carefully in a professional context. Social media can be risky for job seekers who misuse it, and many are making errors. Ironically, social media has been central to the social lives of twentysomethings for years. It was once a place to impress and experiment, often based on fantasy. However, using social media for professional networking is different, and some young people struggle to see this distinction. Our early online presence was bold and confident, which might explain why some still think this approach works. But what worked on Facebook doesn't necessarily work on LinkedIn. We need to meet employers' standards to succeed in the job market. Employers often complain that young job seekers on professional sites are too familiar and seem arrogant, reinforcing the stereotype of an "entitled generation." In reality, many young people are desperate for jobs, which is why they turn to social media. This perceived arrogance can harm their job prospects, even if they have the skills and motivation to be valuable employees. So, how should you contact someone on a professional networking site? First, clearly introduce yourself and explain what you can offer them, like doing research or helping in some way. This approach increases your chances of a positive response. Avoid impersonal, generic messages, and keep a humble tone to prevent negative reactions. Remember, social media can help make valuable connections, but it requires careful use to avoid closing doors.

Text: Predicting the future of newspapers is uncertain. Looking at the numbers, newspapers seem to be in decline. Since 2000, the circulation of most UK national dailies has dropped by a third to half. In the USA, the Pew Research Centre reports that newspapers are now the main news source for only 26% of citizens, down from 45% in 2001. Many predict that printed newspapers will disappear within 15 years. However, history shows that old media often survive. In 1835, a New York journalist claimed that books and theatre were outdated, yet theatre survived newspapers, cinema, and television. Radio thrived alongside TV, and cinema has persisted against videos and DVDs. Even vinyl records have made a comeback, with online sales increasing by 745% since 2008. Newspapers were once new media, taking centuries to become the main news source. This was partly due to technological advances like the steam press, railway, and telegraph in the mid-19th century. Equally important was the new idea that the world is constantly changing and we need regular updates, a concept unfamiliar in medieval times. Today, we expect change. Medieval people saw life as cyclical, marked by seasons and unpredictable disasters like famine or disease. Journalism as a profession barely existed before the 19th century, and there was little reason for regular news updates. Regular newspaper publication can be limiting. Online news allows readers to access information as needed, with search engines and algorithms personalizing news to individual interests. Internet news can provide minute-by-minute updates, correct errors quickly, and offer detailed analysis without space limits. However, online news often focuses on being first, generating comments, and creating noise, rather than spreading understanding. In medieval times, news was shared in noisy marketplaces or taverns, where truth mixed with rumors. We seem to be returning to that environment. Newspapers have struggled to explain how the world works. They might face extinction, or they might find a role in guiding us to wisdom and understanding in a chaotic world.

Text: 'If humans were truly comfortable under the moon and stars, we would move through the night with ease, seeing the midnight world as clearly as many nocturnal animals do. However, we are creatures of the day, with eyes suited for sunlight. This is a fundamental part of our biology, even if we don't often think of ourselves this way. This explains why we have transformed the night by filling it with artificial light. This control is similar to damming a river, bringing benefits but also consequences, known as light pollution. Scientists are just beginning to study its effects. Light pollution mainly comes from poor lighting design, which lets artificial light spread into the sky instead of focusing it downward. This poorly directed light brightens the night, disrupting the natural light levels and rhythms that many life forms, including humans, have adapted to. Wherever artificial light enters the natural world, it affects life processes like migration, reproduction, and feeding. For most of human history, the idea of 'light pollution' would have been meaningless. Imagine approaching London on a moonlit night around 1800, when it was the world's largest city. Nearly a million people lived there, relying on candles, torches, and lanterns. Only a few homes had gas lighting, and public gaslights wouldn't appear for another seven years. From a distance, you would have smelled London before seeing its faint glow. We've illuminated the night as if it were empty, but it's far from that. Among mammals alone, the number of nocturnal species is remarkable. Light is a strong biological force, attracting many species. This attraction is so strong that scientists describe songbirds and seabirds as being 'captured' by searchlights or gas flares, circling until they fall. Birds migrating at night often collide with brightly lit buildings; young birds on their first journey are especially vulnerable. Some birds, like blackbirds and nightingales, sing at odd hours due to artificial light. It was once thought that light pollution only affected astronomers, who need a clear night sky. Unlike astronomers, most of us don't need an unobstructed view of the night sky for work, but like other creatures, we need darkness. Ignoring darkness is pointless. It is as vital to our health as light; disrupting our internal clock can cause health issues. The regular cycle of waking and sleeping reflects the Earth's light cycle. These rhythms are so essential that disturbing them is like changing our balance. Ultimately, humans are as affected by light pollution as frogs near a lit highway. Living in our own glare, we have disconnected from our evolutionary and cultural roots—the stars and the natural day-night cycle. Light pollution makes us lose sight of our true place in the universe, forgetting our scale, which is best understood under a deep night sky with the Milky Way above.'

The founder of a large multinational company recently announced that his company will stop tracking employees' paid holiday time. This decision was inspired by an internet company that has a similar policy. The founder said the idea came from an email from his daughter, which seemed like it was written by his media team. Ignoring the way the announcement was made, we should ask: is this idea practical? The internet company and the multinational corporation are very different. The internet company has 2,000 employees and offers one service, while the multinational has 50,000 employees and many different services like finance, transport, and healthcare. The idea of "take as much time off as you want as long as it doesn't harm the business" might work better in a smaller company where employees know each other's workloads. The founder of the multinational said employees can take as much leave as they want if they are sure their work and team are up to date and their absence won't harm the business or their careers. But can anyone be that sure? No matter how much you prepare, work piles up when you're on holiday. This is just how leave works; you pause your work, but it keeps accumulating. Someone following these rules might not take leave at all or feel guilty about it. Guilt can lead to stress, and not taking enough leave can reduce productivity over time. There might also be pressure from colleagues and office gossip about who takes time off and for how long. This pressure already affects when people start and end their workday. In the corporate world, there's a culture of working late, and this could lead to a "no holiday" culture in a company with unlimited leave, where employees compete for promotions. If the security of statutory leave is removed, people might feel they can't take the leave they need, fearing they look lazy. They wouldn't have their legal rights to rely on. The policy might cause workers to feel unable to take leave or continue using their statutory rights as a guide, making the policy pointless. Modern technology blurs the line between work and leisure, as we can receive work messages anytime, anywhere. The internet company started their unlimited leave policy when employees questioned how this new work style fit with the old time-off policy. If the company can't track work hours accurately, why use an outdated standard for time off? However, without set working hours, all hours could become work hours. Employees might not know if their hours are monitored, leading them to self-discipline, which can be harmful. Employment laws exist for a reason. Workers are entitled to a minimum amount of paid leave because rest is vital for mental and physical health. The benefits of increased morale, creativity, and productivity from unlimited leave can exist without harming worker well-being. I doubt that "taking as much holiday as they want" is the real goal or likely result of this policy.

Text: 'Journal-based peer review is the process where experts in the same field evaluate a scientific research paper. It is seen as a quality check for research, aiming to prevent flawed or nonsensical papers from being published. Scientists often reassure the public about its importance. However, reviewing a paper can delay its publication by up to a year. Is this delay worth it to ensure trustworthy literature? The answer is both yes and no. Examining these issues reveals much about the changing state of scientific publishing. I am not ready to abandon journal-based peer review. I believe all papers should go through some checking before formal publication, but I see changes happening. The rise of preprints—drafts of papers posted online without peer review—is a key part of this change. Preprints focus on quickly sharing new results so they can be read, critiqued, and built upon. Journal publication has become more about reputation and career advancement, which affects both authors' motivations and reviewers' roles. Competition for spots in top journals pushes scientists to do their best work, but also encourages cutting corners, as stories without inconvenient data are more likely to be published. Reviewers now often decide if a manuscript is suitable for the journal, not just if it is good. For top journals, this can depend on how newsworthy a paper is, not just its scientific quality. These issues are known, but few are willing to change the system. However, as biologist Ron Vale recently argued in a preprint, preprints might offer a solution because they don't require a major shift from the norm. Although preprint archives have existed for twenty years, they are not universally used. This slow adoption is due to scientists' conservatism and the misconception that journals won't accept papers posted as preprints. There is also fear that publishing without peer review will lead to 'junk science,' but this hasn't happened yet. Preprints are not peer-reviewed, but authors know they will be critiqued by a global community. Tanya Elks, a psychology professor, shared her experience: 'My paper critiqued a published paper, which is difficult in traditional journals. With anonymous peer review, the original authors might block criticism, or they might not be chosen and could complain about misrepresentation. By posting a preprint, the original authors could respond, and we could consider their points. All comments are public, so readers can judge the arguments' quality. Rejection by journals is less of a concern since the preprint and comments are public, so our work isn't wasted.' Preprint archives allow global scientific discussions that were once private. They could also be a place for negative results, an important part of science often ignored by journals focused on new discoveries. Preprints increase how often papers are read and cited, showing their effectiveness in sharing research. By using the web's openness and the collaborative spirit in science, preprints can help focus on the work itself, not where it is published.'

When I ask my literature students to define a poem, they often say it’s like ‘a painting in words’. These answers rarely satisfy anyone. One day, I asked them to choose an object and write two paragraphs: one describing it scientifically, and another from the object's perspective, titled ‘Poem’. A student wrote: 

Poem: I may look strange or scary, but I’m a device that helps people breathe. I’m used only in emergencies and for a short time. Most people will never need me. 

The object? An oxygen mask. This unusual choice helped the class see how poetry works in a unique way. The exercise sparked laughter and meaningful discussion. 

In school, poetry often seemed confusing to me, like a puzzle blocking true understanding and emotion. After school, many people lose interest in poetry. Occasionally, you encounter a poem, and it stands out because it’s not continuous prose. It challenges you to read it, and often leaves you feeling let down or confused. Still, you feel good for trying. 

What do we seek in poems? Aren’t they meant to hold deep feelings, vivid images, tender thoughts, or sharp wit? The answer seems to be yes. But for tears, we turn to films; for information or critique, we read articles. Novels offer escape, paintings please the eye, and music combines lyrics, instruments, and melody in a sublime way. 

Yet, a poem offers something unique: ambiguity. Life is full of it, unlike straightforward reading. But this doesn’t fully explain what a poem is. An online search for ‘poem’ leads to ‘poetry’: ‘a form of literary art using aesthetic and rhythmic qualities of language’. This academic definition misses the word’s roots. ‘Poem’ comes from the Greek poí?ma, meaning ‘a thing made,’ and a poet is ‘a maker of things.’ 

So, if a poem is a thing made, what kind of thing is it? Poets sometimes liken poems to wild animals – untameable and unpredictable – or to machines – precise and engineered. But these comparisons don’t hold up under scrutiny. The value in comparing poems lies in the discussion it provokes. Whether you see a poem as a machine or a wild animal, this process can change how you view machines or wild animals. It helps the mind explore new ways of thinking, making us see familiar things differently. 

The idea of a poem as a mental object is not far-fetched, especially when we think of how song lyrics stick in our minds. The mix of words and melody is powerful, like schoolyard rhymes. But aren’t words sometimes like sticks and stones? 

Consider a poem in a newspaper or magazine: it can impact you like nothing else, even though it’s just ink on paper like the prose around it. What about the white space around the poem – space that could be used for a longer article or ad? A poem is written and rewritten like an article, story, or novel, but it doesn’t become a commodity like they do. Publishers promote poetry collections, but few expect them to cover printing costs. A poem is not for the marketplace, but for its own sake. Because of its special status in a magazine or book, a poem can still surprise us, even if just for a moment.

I bought my first metal detector soon after I got married. Back then, £70 was a lot of money and could have been used for something more practical for the house. However, my wife, Marion, was impressed when I found a gold ring worth £80 on my first try. Over the years, every brooch and coin I've found has brought me joy because it connects me to the past. But after the gold ring, it took 40 years to find something else that impressed Marion as much. 

One dull February afternoon, I had a couple of hours free and a place in mind to search. It was raining, so I chose a closer spot known for old farming machinery. The first time my detector beeped, I found a piece of a metal wheel. Then it beeped again. I tried to ignore it but couldn't leave without checking. I dug down half a metre and was lying in the mud when I saw a rounded, golden ball. I had found brass curtain rails before, so I tried not to get too excited. But as I cleared more dirt, the ball turned into a thick, intricately patterned loop. I stopped and stared, then remembered to breathe. It looked like the Great Torc, a famous Iron Age necklace in the British Museum. 

I took it to the car and kept looking at it on the drive home. I washed it in the kitchen sink, probably the first clean it had in over 2,000 years. ‘Marion!’ I called, ‘I've got something for you.’ She came in, stopped, and asked, ‘What is it?’ I explained it was a very old and rare piece of jewellery. We didn't try it on because we didn't want to damage it. At bedtime, I hid it in our wardrobe. We had never been burgled, but I was anxious. Eventually, I got up, unscrewed a floorboard in my office, and hid it there. 

The law says such finds must be reported within 14 days. I wanted to enjoy the torc as much as possible before giving it up. I even took it in a plastic bag to show a friend in the hospital. Finally, I took it to the council office in the same bag. The registrar was talking to someone when I placed the torc on his desk. He turned, still talking, then stopped mid-sentence. The torc was authenticated and sold to my local council. It's now in the British Museum in London. The £350,000 proceeds were split between the field's owner and me. But the torc is more than just a lucky find. It's something I've saved for the nation. People ask, ‘Now that you've found something so amazing, will you stop detecting?’ But those brooches and coins are still interesting. Besides, if a fisherman catches a big fish, he doesn't stop fishing—not when there's a chance of catching an even bigger one tomorrow.

Sleeping is one of my favorite parts of traveling, but I don't often talk about it because I feel a bit guilty. When friends describe their carefully planned trips, filled with activities like visiting museums and hiking, I just smile and listen. What would they think if they knew my travel plans include time for afternoon naps during Caribbean rainstorms and lazy mornings in Italian sheets? Better sleep is a happy side effect of travel. When I visited Mexico's Yucatán coast in my early 20s, I was surprised by how much I slept—over 12 hours most days. Despite noisy birds nearby, I could sleep deeply and dreamily, more than I thought possible. Free from alarms and responsibilities, sleep comes more easily. But I think there's more to it than just relaxing. I believe sleep is part of the travel experience, not just a break from it. Traveling exposes us to new sights, sounds, and smells. We absorb new cultures, music, and landscapes. Sleep helps us process this flood of new experiences, making it more intense. Sleep also changes with each place. People worry about jet lag, but I think adjusting to local customs affects me more than time zones. In Trinidad, for example, people wake early to avoid the heat, rest around 10 a.m., and become active again in the evening. Even though Trinidad is only one hour ahead of New York, it takes me days to adjust to this pattern. Once I do, I feel like I've truly arrived. I remember an afternoon in Santo Domingo, where I shared a big meal with new friends. After eating, we all relaxed on hammocks and sofas. I realized why there were so many pillows around. I joined in and experienced the Latin American tradition of the siesta, sharing not just sleep but a piece of Dominican life. Travel sleep is memorable. Away from my usual routine, I enjoy the new smells, textures, and sounds that fill my dreams. If 'slow travel' means savoring every experience rather than rushing, then what is slower than sleep? Maybe I should stop feeling embarrassed and tell my friends that travel sleep is an activity too.

The woman turned away from the mirror. "What do you think? And be honest." Mia picked up a medium-sized hat with a soft layer of gauze and a silk bow. "I still think this one suits you best," she said diplomatically to her customer. The woman wrinkled her nose and frowned, looking a bit like a bulldog. "But it's so boring," she complained. "Everyone will wear a hat like that at my daughter’s wedding. This little beauty will make me stand out." She patted the red and black miniature top hat on her head. "Yes," she decided, "this is the one I want." Mia knew she couldn't change her mind, so she smiled and agreed that the woman would indeed stand out at the wedding. She thought of her own daughter, Jen, whose thirtieth birthday was today. They were having a family gathering, and Mia was excited to see Jen, Dan, and Luke. She was also curious about Jen's friend, Tattie, whom they knew nothing about. When Jen had called last week to ask if she could bring Tattie, Mia's husband Jeff had questioned the name. "Tattie?" he said. "What sort of name is that?" "It's short for Tatiana," Mia replied. "I think it’s nice." Jeff, who disliked anything pretentious, had no patience for affectation. He also believed in speaking his mind, unlike Mia, who he thought was too polite. He would have told the woman in the shop that she was choosing the wrong hat, perhaps even suggesting a dustbin lid would suit her better. "The trouble with you, Mia," he often said, "is that you’re too polite for your own good." An hour later, Mia closed her shop and entered Medlar House through the back door. Her commute was only forty seconds. Four years ago, when their youngest child, Luke, left home, Mia decided to convert the unused barn next to their house into a bright space for her business. Jeff was doubtful. "Do you really think there's a demand for hats?" he asked. Mia knew from friends that there was a demand for the perfect hat for special occasions. She was right. After Jen helped her create a website, Mia’s Hats became a success. Women traveled from afar to her showroom in Little Pelham, where they could try on as many hats as needed in a relaxed setting. She encouraged customers to bring their outfits to ensure a perfect match. Recently, she expanded her business to include handbags and costume jewelry.

Text: 'Lawrence Okoye has traveled a long way from London to Atlanta, reflecting on his remarkable sports journey. Despite never having played American football, he is likely to be chosen for a major USA team. In Atlanta, he is learning the responsibilities of his new position. The idea that a 21-year-old from London could be selected for a top American team is surprising, but Lawrence is used to defying expectations. He was offered a place at Oxford University to study law but postponed it to focus on discus, after playing rugby. Within 20 months, he became the world’s fourth-best discus thrower. Lawrence originally went to Atlanta for warm-weather discus training, aiming for the world championships. He confirms his sudden interest in an NFL contract: ‘American football was in the back of my mind, but I decided to try it when I got to the USA. At school in London, it seemed crazy.’ Soon after arriving, he learned about NFL trials in Atlanta. Despite never playing the game, he applied and was chosen as the most impressive player in tests and drills. ‘I was very pleased to hear that,’ he says, showing rare pride. However, he is cautious, acknowledging his lack of experience. ‘Coaches say I have the attributes needed. It’s about how hard I work,’ he explains. He remains calm about the selection process: ‘There’s no pressure on me. People say I’ll be selected, but I’m not too worried.’ This calmness might stem from his Olympic disappointment, where he finished last in the discus final. He has moved past this, proud of qualifying for the final with an impressive last throw. ‘That was an amazing day,’ he recalls. ‘The final didn’t go as planned, but that’s sport. I can return to it.’ After the Olympics, some thought the experience had affected him, but Lawrence doesn’t comment. The minimum NFL salary is over $400,000 a year, making the financial benefits clear. Lawrence has switched from rugby to athletics and now to American football. With his talents, wouldn’t it be better to focus on one sport? ‘I understand why someone would say that,’ he replies. ‘I’m trying to achieve a dream I’ve had since school. If it doesn’t work out, I can return to discus, the sport I love. Every decision I’ve made has been thought through.’'

We had been flying east all night, and I woke up to see it was already daylight. Looking out the window at the empty landscape below, the dark shades of brown and green reassured me that, although it was mid-September, winter had not yet arrived in Siberia. I saw no signs of human life, just an endless view of mountains, streams, and forests. I shook my head. My neighbor woke up and smiled at me sleepily. "Good morning, Robert," he said in a slow, Russian accent. Sergei was a salesman from Moscow traveling to remote areas to sell safety clothing to local mining industries. His English was almost as poor as my Russian, but with a dictionary, I explained that I was flying to the far-eastern Siberian city of Magadan with a one-way ticket because I planned to return to England by bicycle. "But, Robert," he said, "there is no road from Magadan; you cannot ride a bicycle." I told him I believed there was a road, though not many people used it. "Alone?" he asked. "No, I will be riding with a friend named Al." "Just one friend?" "Yes, just one," I nodded. Sergei still looked doubtful and pointed outside, saying "Holodna" (cold). I tried to reassure him with hand gestures that I had warm clothes, though I didn't mention that my trip was self-funded and I was on a tight budget. Most of my clothes and equipment were bought at discounted prices. I wasn't sure they would be adequate, especially my large postman’s over-trousers, which I bought for £10. It all started in a lecture hall in Scotland. The hall was full of students slumped in their seats, some taking notes without energy. The lecturer droned on. I was thinking about a dilemma. Should I ask him or not? "Well, why not?" I tore a fresh sheet from my pad and wrote, "Hi Al, Do you want to cycle across the Karakorum Highway between Pakistan and China this summer? Rob." In the row in front of me sat Al, my old school friend. I tapped him on the shoulder and passed the note. He tried to read my handwriting, scratched his head, wrote something, and passed it back. I unfolded it and held my breath while I read. "OK," it said. Six years later, I was going to join Al in Siberia. I had been working as a geography teacher, and although I was still learning to manage my classes, the job was fulfilling. It was challenging, rarely boring, and there were long holidays for adventures. Twice since I started teaching, I had used these holidays to meet Al. He had caught the adventure bug after our bike ride through Pakistan and decided to do something more relaxing than teaching: cycling around the world. Since our first ride together, Al had been setting himself greater challenges. This round-the-world bike trip was his greatest so far. At times, he thought the ride or the road would break him. Although it sounded tough, I envied him. He was having an extraordinary adventure, finding he could handle each new challenge, even if it seemed impossible. He was proving the skeptics wrong. He was doing something that scared him nearly every day, and it made him feel alive.
